novel_text:
When the haar slips down from the Forth and takes hold of the wynds and closes, the city makes itself small. Noise goes away. Colours go to sleep. Victorine does not. She lifts a shutter with her thumb as a child might lift a curtain of ivy, and stoops to peer in at a mirror, at the slick red curve of a young man’s mouth as he practices a smile he means for someone else.

He does not see her. He sees only himself and the glass of his phone. His name will not be said here because it does not last; names do not last, though they hold so much. What lasts is the soft mica gleam of his lower lip, the crooked left edge where he bit it once. He swallows. He has no idea that she is already holding him in her light.

The camera is not delicate. It is weighty as a dictionary and more decisive. She cradles it in two palms so large the strap is a ribbon. It snaps. A bright box chirrups, and the image starts to slide from its mouth.

“Please, hold still,” Victorine whispers, almost polite. The man pauses, startled by nothing he can place. His reflection is rose-tinted by the bar’s lamps. Her voice is soft, a warmer fog within the fog, the breath that runs along a spine, not cold exactly but aware.

Everything she does is for love, because of love, fuelled by the kind that legends threaten you with and prayers secretly beg for. When she kneels, plants groan under her knee and the cobbles decide to remember the weight of giants. Love asks enormous things. It asks her to follow, and she follows.

She has learned streets by the taste of them. The brine taste of Leith. The green-copper taste at the foot of the Scott Monument. The soot-and-rain taste of Cowgate where laughter falls like bottles into a bin. She leans to catch the edges, the details. The hair above a lip like a handful of barley. A mouth like a hinge. A mouth like a wound a little healed. She does not see faces. Not really. She has trained herself to see only the boundary where voice becomes world: the lips.

Her camera coughs another square. She tucks the prints in a pouch at her belt, an old belt, old leather softened by oil and her own enormous warmth. The prints are damp and their shadows are still swimming into shape. It matters this — that they arrive slowly, that they have time to learn themselves. She hums to them. A small tune. It sounds like one lamp left on in the kitchen after a party, a yellow place for talking when the music has gone. She hums and the fog listens.

“Oi,” says someone. It is the boy’s friend at last, shaking his phone like a torch. “You coming or what?”

The young man leaves the mirror with a last little check, that crooked edge quick, a rehearsal repeated. He goes and is gone, and Victorine takes a picture of the space where his mouth had been and tucks that away too. Nothing is lost. Nothing is about to be lost, she promises herself. The bag of mouths knocks against her thigh. She rises, her shoulder briefly shouldering the low cloud that makes her hair damp, and she goes.

On the other side of the city, in the yellow light of a restaurant that is always almost closing, Mr Cook slides two panna cottas onto a tray and balances a single espresso between them like a jewel in a setting. The espresso is for the woman at table four who has talked for forty minutes about a man who does not love her. The panna cottas are for the two quiet boys at table nine who keep looking at the door.

“Be careful with that,” Lorna says, summoning the espresso with the twitch of a hand made perfect by seventeen years of this. “She’s the sort who sues.”

“She’s the sort who is already disappointed,” Mr Cook says. He is not unkind about it; he has learned to name things and move along. He moves along rather well. He wears black with a grey apron over it and his shoes are not fashionable but they are clean and he has his mother’s shoulders on his father’s bones. People call him Mr Cook because it’s printed there on the receipt when they split their bill and write Don't forget Mr Cook! in the tip line with a little heart. It amuses him. He has a first name like anyone else. He has not used it much lately.

Outside, the fog pushes its soft face against the panes and leaves a sheen. Mr Cook looks up and the sheen shivers, as if someone very large has breathed. He does not yet do the thing he will do, which is step outside and be ridiculous and useful at once. He delivers desserts, retrieves a credit card from beneath a bread plate, laughs when laughed at, receives a story he didn’t ask for, and when it is all done he locks the door himself because the owner has gone home and because tonight, as so many nights, the city is a little unattached and requires someone to say yes, there, the end, we are closed, we are safe.

“Did you hear,” Lorna says, tying a scarf so bright it raises the room a degree, “about the thing down by Dean Village? About the odd footprints in the mud like— like something that had no business wearing shoes?”

“There are a hundred things with no business wearing shoes,” Mr Cook says. He washes his hands again by habit. The tap squeals; his wrists are thin, the tendons trick strings. “Was it you out there in the mud looking for news?”

“It was my cousin’s boyfriend’s pal and it was on his story,” she says. “It had that little face you can add with the sick eyebrows, you know.”

“I can just about manage an email,” Mr Cook says. “Don’t ask me for eyebrows.” He dries his hands. He has a particular way of folding towels into the drawer, so they open all the same way, like books ready at the library. The order is not about fear. It is about harm reduction. That’s what his therapist called it once, back when he could afford a therapist. He could afford one again now, he supposes, but then who would he talk to about it? He thinks of talking. He does not call anyone.

“Right,” Lorna says, and glances through the fog toward the street. “You going home?”

“In a minute,” he says. “I like to wait for the dishwasher to finish so I know it is not going to flood and murder us all in our sleep.”

“You’re a poet, Mr Cook.”

He is not a poet. He can’t keep a line in his head to save it. He says goodnight and watches the door seal itself around Lorna as she peels herself away into the city and the city takes her back, as it always does. He listens to the dishwasher and the tick of the clock on the wall that is chronically slow because its battery is a traitor. At last he shuts the last lights and steps into the grey.

He walks home on a route that is not the shortest but is the one he likes because it carries him along the Water of Leith, where the world is narrower and there are foxes who are not troubled by men. His shoes make soft sounds. A bus sighs out on the big road, sounding like someone who has decided to try again anyway.

It happens quickly, in the kind of quiet that belongs to a church and a bus station at 2 a.m. The path dips and curves and he is in a little hollow made by trees and walls, and ahead of him is not a fox. The thing ahead is a shadow and then a corner of someone’s coat and then — a face, but not the face, because what he sees is the mouth and what he sees past the mouth is the hand that lifts something heavy and square.

“Hey,” Mr Cook says, a thing to say when you see something odd but not yet a reason to panic. “You all right?”

It is a boy, maybe twenty. He has the pale skin of a person who has spent too many nights helping bars fill their bins. He is focusing on staying upright. He’s focused on his phone. He does not turn. The person with the heavy square does not turn, either, and Mr Cook sees then that the heavy square is a camera, old-looking and severe.

He hears it: the little animal machine sound. Dispatch. The boy’s mouth is pink in the flash. His lips, to be precise, and they are very slightly chapped, the kind of chapping from kissing in the cold and not from a deficiency in chapstick. The flash is not a flash — it is more like the fog catching fire and then deciding not to.

“Hey,” Mr Cook says again, and now there is purpose in it. He takes a stride nearer. The person holding the camera raises a hand as if to say wait. The hand is not possible. It is very large. Not big like rugby. Large like door. Large like a kind of slow-falling weather.

“That’s close enough,” the person says. A woman’s voice, low and apologetic and thick with something like rain. “I won’t hurt you. I’m — I’m working.”

“You’re what?” He stops on the word working because there is a comedy to it and the comedy is a place he can breathe. “You’re working? At this hour? Is it for a magazine?”

“No,” she says. “It is for someone I love,” and God help everyone, she means it.

He sees her as the fog moves just a little. She cannot be as tall as the trees. She cannot be alive, not at that size and angle, the Firth smell on her hair and the wet of a long walk under a low sky. She is stooping. She is trying to be shy. Her coat is stitched from a tent, or from something that once had a mast, and her face is as careful as a librarian's hand about to turn a fragile page.

The boy mutters, “Mate?” to nobody exactly. He is free, and does not know it yet. He has been captured and released. The photograph slides out like a tongue. The boy’s friend howls from the bridge that he is paying for the taxi without him. He goes up to the bridge in pieces — not literally; in that drunken way that life becomes composed of stairs and breath and stairs.

Victorine holds the picture to make it warm. She looks up at Mr Cook and for a moment something like an understanding visits them with the fog: neither of them wants to frighten what is already always frightened. It is an odd moment to be introduced.

“You’re a giant,” he says, because he is a simple man in a complicated room.

“Yes,” she says. “And you’re a waiter.”

The answer is so exact it tips him forward. “I don’t usually bring the desserts down here,” he says. The joke falls and makes a small sound somewhere near the water.

“I won’t hurt them,” she says. She nods toward the bridge. The camera strap swings like a black river on her shoulder. “I am making a book. I am making proof. I am—”

She doesn’t know what she is. She stops.

“What is it,” he asks, “you’re proving?”

“That I loved him,” she says. “That I know where the voice comes from when it kisses. That I can make him out of the world even though the world keeps eating him.”

Words like that are a danger. They are too bare. They are a sore you have picked clean and now it gleams, slick and helpless. He is used to plates; he is not used to this. He hears, as if from a distance, his own voice shape a question that is not his own: “Who?”

“You don’t know him,” she says, and the disappointment in that is mild and absolute, a weather pattern that determines crops. “He is no one. He is everyone. Don’t worry. It is not a murder, what I am doing. It is the opposite of murder.” She produces the second photograph and holds them side by side, two boys’ mouths already turning toward themselves, becoming, in the way of such pictures, both more real and more partial. “There,” she says. “Look how they try to say, even when they are doing nothing, one more thing.”

“Please don’t,” he says. He has no right to say it. He says it anyway, as someone might reach for a glass falling. “They’re not for you. And if they were, you would not be able to keep them safe.”

“Who keeps anything safe,” she says, not unkindly. “What do you keep safe? The panna cottas? The teaspoons?” She looks out over the black water. “I keep these. I keep them.”

He should call someone. He should turn and run and find a phone box like a film and telephone the police. He should move, should make a simple ordinary sound that will break the enchantment and make her regular sized. But the fog does not allow for ordinary; the water is a dark semaphore; she is a shape written on the stone buildings by a hand that is used to writing in the margins.

“My name is Mr Cook,” he says, and this time it sounds like a line he might like to keep. “And I think you’re frightening them whether you mean to or not. And anyway — anyway you can’t go about at night taking folk’s…”

“Lips,” she says, helpful.

“Photographs,” he says, and pinches the bridge of his nose to keep his thoughts from slope. “Photographs.”

“I can,” she says. “And I will. I have to finish before the world changes and starts to sing a different song.”

“What happens if you don’t,” he asks. He cannot stop himself.

She considers this in the way someone might consider the speed of a train they are about to miss. “He will close his mouth,” she says. “He will close it forever. And I will never hear it again.”

“Who,” he says, useless, and just then a fox crosses their path with a piece of bread in its mouth and the world opens its hands again and the fog rolls with the contentment of a cat that has chosen a lap.

They stand like that for a breath. She is much too big, and he is much too brave and not enough. She tucks the two photographs away. She steps back once, twice. The trees list as if a wind had changed direction.

“I’m sorry if you are frightened,” she says. “Please tell them they are beautiful and that they do not know it yet.”

“Everyone tells them that,” he says. “That is the particular curse of them. It is why they keep going out.”

“That is good then,” she says, as if that settled anything. She nods, a serious tilt, and then she is gone, as in gone. Not slowly. It is a series of edits: her shoulder, her hand, the shadow made by her knee, the leaf that had been stuck to her coat, the idea of her. The fog unknots. He is alone. He does not call anyone. He goes home, and his bedsheets are cold.

In the morning the city acts as if it has always been an honest saxophone. Ten o’clock light bends itself around corners; cats repair themselves. Mr Cook drinks a coffee that tastes like soil and rain and suspicion. He doesn’t speak of it at the restaurant because he will be laughed at and because it is not that kind of story. He will tell it one day to someone he has not yet met; not now. Now is for orders and orders up.

A group of students come in with scarves and hangover faces and say things like “the vibe in here” and “I’m literally starving” and laugh as if that were legal. Two young men sit near the window and arrange themselves in the light so their skin could be listened to by cameras. He finds he is watching their mouths. He takes orders and tries not to make a cathedral out of everything.

“Make an exception,” Lorna says, pushing him with an elbow as she reaches for a glass. “Come out tonight. We’ll go up to the Meadows, there’s a thing on. Food trucks. Music. People. You can’t sit in your flat with your radio on like an old man choking on the shipping forecast.”

“I will do that exact thing,” Mr Cook says. “I am a creature of habit, and my habit is loneliness.”

“Liar,” she says, and she is right; the habit is attention. He lives on watching. You can tell things, what people want, what they will eat, what they came here to be told about themselves. He is a doctor of menus and an amateur hydrologist of shame. He has watched so long that it is a kind of marriage.

He goes to the Meadows. He does. It is all too bright. The bands sound like they have just read a note about how to be joyous and are trying it out for the first time. People sit on damp grass anyway because they are young and invincible and because their trousers are not expensive. He buys a paper plate of noodles so hot the steam becomes political. He stands and he watches mouths.

Victorine is not there. Of course she is not there. She does not like daylight. She does not like crowds except as a field in which mouths bloom and she can visit like a bee at night. But there is a rumour that she is always not far, a gravitational wrongness, and when someone laughs there is an extra beat after it where you might hear a camera settle itself against a palm like a bird on a wrist.

Mr Cook hears nothing. He sees nothing. He goes home later by a route he does not usually take and discovers, in a lane behind a chemist, a photograph pinned to a corkboard among flyers for rooms to let and a man with a van: a small square of lips. No face. No eyes. Just a mouth slightly open and the pink, faintly wet interior where someone else’s name would sit before it came out. The photograph has a small pin through one corner. It is labelled in a hand that has to be big: Aidan, Fountainbridge, likes sugar.

He takes it. He does not know why he does this except that it feels like an act of theft in favour of the world. He has a drawer with coasters and spare keys and packets of soy sauce, all the items that are both useful and in the wrong place. He puts the photograph there. He does not sleep well. He dreams of kissing his own knuckles because they are familiar.

The days turn. Victorine goes about her work like a tide with a timetable. She knows the stairwells where boys pause to check their breath. She knows the bathrooms in pubs where boys rehearse expressions. She knows which nights they will go home alone and which nights they will walk too fast and which nights they will make a loved one of a stranger for a bit. She does not take them. She takes only the soft space at the edge of being taken: the lips.

Streetlights oblige her. Sometimes they are kind, and the sodium makes the mouths golden as a harvest; sometimes they are brutal, and everything is blue and exact; sometimes the light is only the phone, and then the light is a kiss of its own. She hums, and the humming becomes a sound that young men do not know they hear and it makes them stand still for two seconds longer than they would have.

There are stories. Boys tell boys. They say there is a woman who looks at your mouth and you forget your name and for the next week you bite the inside of your cheek and it tastes like someone else’s cigarettes. They say she brings luck. They say she is a monster. They say she is tall. They say she is a camera with a person attached. They say not to go over the bridge. They go over the bridge.

Mr Cook grows a habit that is not so different from his other habits. He walks home later. He will not admit to himself that he is looking for her because that would be romance, and he does not have the warranty for romance. He checks corkboards now. He sees more of the squares. Always the lips. Always a little name, a little detail. Harvey, Tollcross, whistles. Jamal, Holyrood, hates olives. Finn, Stockbridge, sings in the shower. He takes one. He leaves another. He is a thief and a curator. He has a tiny museum of mouths, ridiculous, secret.

“No offence,” Lorna says when she comes round one night because the heating is broken in her place and his is not, “but your walls are a wee bit bare for a person with feelings.”

“I have a selection of photographs of people’s mouths,” he says, and waits for her to ask. She does not, lately. She has seen stranger. She warms her hands at his radiator and tells him about a man with a moustache that requires insurance.

“What are you going to do with your life,” she asks finally, not like a scold but like a friend who knows that life is a cupboard you avoid opening because the saucepan lids are waiting to jump out.

“This,” he says. “This is probably it.” He does not sound sad. It is not sad. There is so much to do, plates to catch, forks to deliver. Still. He presses his thumb against the edge of a photograph in the drawer and feels its small precise pain.

On a Wednesday that has not made up its mind to rain or not, the newspaper prints a story that is trying to be cheerful about the crime it is reporting. Missing: two young men last seen on separate streets. They are not the first missing. The city is a large, complicated cupboard. The paper cites family members. It uses the phrase out of character. It uses the phrase police appeal. It uses pictures taken from social media and the mouths in the pictures are of course there, loud and patterned with the imperfections that make all beauty possible.

Mr Cook eats his toast without tasting it and folds the newspaper twice and then again and then puts it out for the recycling as if it were a dangerous bottle. At work he pours a pint too quickly and has to let it settle like a mood. He does not speak. Lorna speaks. Lorna speaks enough for two. It helps. It almost addresses the problem. He is not stupid. He is arranging his fear on a shelf. He is also choosing a time and a place.

He walks down to Dean Village after midnight, when the stone looks like skin and the water looks like a language you half remember how to read. He waits on the path. Foxes skitter. Students skid. He waits. He does not call her name because he does not know it. He has named her three different things and none of them stuck. He waits.

She arrives like weather you hear about from other towns first. A smell of salt. The sense that the mass of the air has been miscalculated. He hears the strap of the camera before he sees her, the leather song of it. He stands up, because he had been sitting like a pen lid on a bench, and his legs are pins.

“You,” she says, not surprised. “You are the waiter.”

“And you are the proof,” he says. His hands are at his sides. He would like to be much braver than he is and much stupider; he would like to be the person who runs at a giant with a broom handle shouting be off with you, foul spirit, be gone back to where you came from. He is not that person. He is a person with a good memory for orders. “What is your name?”

“I have had too many,” she says, but he hears something in it this time, a slip, the echo of a letter. “Victorine,” she says eventually, and the name falls like a coin into a box that didn’t know it was hungry. “Victorine.”

“All right,” he says. “Victorine, I’m asking you. You have to stop.”

She looks at him as if he has asked her to take her heart out and boil it for tea. “I am nearly done,” she says. The pictures at her belt are thicker. The belt bows, tired under the weight of proof. “I am making a gift. He will be complete soon.”

“Who,” he says again, stubborn in the way a door is stubborn when the paint has stuck. “Who is he.”

“He was small,” she says, as if she is reading from a list in her mind that is written in a child’s handwriting. “He had a laugh like teeth. He kept money in his left shoe. He told jokes that were stolen from someone else and tried to blush when caught, but he could not. His mother called him a big daft boy in a way that meant stay.”

“Everyone,” Mr Cook says gently, and he can hear it, the grief, the bigness of love that made a person huge because how else can you carry it, “has a him like that.”

“Yes,” she says. “And everyone is failing him. I will not.”

“They are disappearing,” he says, each word a plate he cannot drop. “Boys. Men. The newspaper. This is not nothing. I don’t know what it is yet, but it’s not nothing.”

“I am not taking them,” she says, scornful now and with a hurt that makes the river lower itself. “I would never. I am collecting only the outer map of a voice. If something is happening it is happening without me.”

He believes her. He hates that he does. He swears inwardly with small careful words. He looks at the black slots of the closes and at the lights in a few windows where the late ones draw. “Then help me,” he says, surprising himself with the taste of the word help. “If you know their routes and their habits, if you know their mouths you may know the rest. Help me find what is wrong. Please.”

She is enormous and she is tender like a streetlamp in fog. She looks at him. “You are a waiter,” she repeats, as if this were an ancestry.

“And you are a giant,” he says. “We are neither of us quite trained for this.”

“You will do it anyway,” she says. It is not a question, and in the not a question is all of the disaster and all of the devotion of what will happen next.

She gives him a photograph. He flinches because it feels like a kind of coupling, to be given something like that. It is a mouth with a little scar above it, a moon of a scar. It is labelled Kellan, Marchmont, left-handed. “He is missing,” she says simply. “He did not come home. His brother cried in the street but he did not keep the tears. He wiped them on his sleeve and threw the sleeve away.”

“What time,” Mr Cook asks. He hates the procedural sound of him. He nods at his own nodding and dislikes himself. “Where.”

“Here,” she says. “An hour after I saw him. He was merry. He was singing a song that told the street what it was, silly man. I took his lips. Then he was gone.”

The river is loud as if it wants to be a witness. They stand like judges who are not allowed to sit and like children who are not allowed to speak. Mr Cook feels the hinge of his next few months seal.

“All right,” he says. “Tell me everything. Every boy you saw that night. Every lip. Every wrongness.”

She tells him. She has a memory like the city. Fussy. Fond. She does not miss a thing once she has decided it is worth not missing. He writes nothing down. He will keep it in his head for later. He will go back and back. He will ask questions that offend. He will dress them as if they were amuse-bouches and everyone will swallow them without thinking. He will stalk the way a waiter stalks during a rush — not predatory, not noble. Necessary.

“You will get hurt,” Victorine says by way of a benediction.

“I am perpetually already hurt,” he says without self-pity and the night accepts that.

She rises as if the ground had been holding her by the ankle in a memory and lets go. He feels the shift of air. She is patient with her largeness. She treads lightly and still the city knows and the city forgives her. She goes and the bench is a bench again and the river is a river again and Mr Cook is a man in a coat who will now have to go and be more than a waiter and more than a man who owns eight photographs he would have to explain by leaving the country.

If you asked him to tell you the thing that began it all, he would say the fog moving and the camera sound, an old technology making a small creature noise. He would say the way her hand lifted, apologetic, and how his own hand did not lift back in fear. He would say he saw her love and it was bleeding out of her like light.

He would also say a very plain and silly thing, which is: He had had enough of being the one who cleared away what was left after. He wanted to be first at the table. He wanted to be the one who put something down on it that mattered. He put down his soul then. Or something like that. Something that looks like a napkin in the right light, folded a particular way. He would smile when he said it and you would not know whether to believe him or not. He would like that. He has always liked giving other people options.

In the weeks that follow, as the city keeps singing its long song about itself and the notices go up and down on noticeboards and the photographs travel in secret from a belt to a drawer to a fist, people will say there came a change. It is not a change anyone can nail to a date. It is not about weather though the weather does its part. It is the way doors are opened at different speeds. It is the way boys check the corners of their mouths for honesty. It is the way a waiter asks too many questions without making anyone feel interrogated.

It is the way a giant, who wanted only to collect enough light to call love true, finds herself participating in a hunt she did not intend and will pay for. It is the way a city, which is so old it should not be surprised by anything, takes a breath and holds it a long time.It begins with a map that is not a map, a paper placemat from the restaurant which Mr Cook has turned to the blank side and sectioned with a biro into neighbourhoods that only he recognises. He draws the Water of Leith like a vein he has learned how to find with two fingers and a patience learned from waiting for kettles. He dots pubs, and the long elastic places between them where boys stretch into their futures under streetlights and mistake the stretching for destiny. He writes names in margins and facts in the places where bread plates would go. It looks ridiculous. It is unshakeable.

He takes the placemat to the kitchen and tapes it under the bottom shelf where Lorna will not find it until she kneels to reach the last bag of sugar and then he will have to explain himself without warning. He likes the risk. It makes him feel like a person with a room in his life that is not visible from the front door. That room smells of warmed milk and pencilled lines and foxes crossing narrower spaces than you would think a fox could cross.

The first thing he learns is that he has already been learning all along. It turns out that watching the angle at which a man lifts his glass is not so different from watching the angle at which a man stops to check his reflection. It turns out that knowing which table wants to order dessert but needs to be told it is not embarrassing is the same skill as recognising which young man has decided to be brave because he has almost been caught by something and wants to prove the city wrong. He does not call the police because the police would do what the police do; he is doing harm reduction in a room that does not have a sign saying that. He carries in his head a list of other people’s sons and the places their mouths were last known to be speaking.

He goes to Marchmont because Kellan had a scar, and scars have councils they belong to. He visits the shop where a woman sits behind a counter selling stamps and lottery tickets and invites good luck to cross the threshold in increments. He asks if she remembers a boy who paid for cigarettes with a five-pound note folded into a square as if it were a secret letter. She does not. He goes next door and asks a man who has cut the same heads of hair for twenty years to notice that the wind changed last week. The man says that boys come and go and that their mouths always smile when they look at themselves, never when they look at other people. The man is barber-cynical about it; he is not wrong, but he is lazy with the truth.

There is a bouncer outside a place with a name that suggests a speakeasy but which only speaks loudly. The bouncer has a stool he refuses to sit on because he does not intend to get comfortable. Mr Cook has brought him coffee before because kindness is a tourism guide that gets you behind the rope. He brings one now. He asks about Kellan without saying missing, and the bouncer’s eyes put together the letters anyway and they move with a faint tiredness that looks like respect. He saw Kellan leave around one with two friends; one of the friends can sing any song that begins with a U, for a bet. They turned right, towards the Meadows. There was fog in that direction, a fog that looked like it had a schedule.

In the Meadows he finds trampled grass in round shapes where friends had sat themselves and their doubts in rings. He walks the paths and watches the mouths of the statues, because he is superstitious in a slow way, and he asks a hot chocolate truck if they recognise a boy with a scar. The hot chocolate truck has the manners of a small house; it invites and it sticks to its opinions. The woman working there says there were two lads who came late and asked for extra cream and wrote their initials on the lids like it was a contract. She had thought about it later because the initials were the same except for one letter and it felt like a game she wasn’t a part of.

It is nothing. It is everything. He notes it on his placemat map when he gets home, the letter that was not the same, the cream that was extra as if sweetness were an armour. He does not sleep, but this is not important because sleep is a place he has lately disliked. In the morning he will take croissants from a paper bag that lies about its own flakiness, and he will butter them like forgiveness and feed himself the way one feeds a dog that has done something almost clever.

Victorine does not have a map because she is the map. She has walked the city until the city walked her back, until she could tell you the taste of every bridge and the sound of every close when it swallows you and makes you echo. She did not intend to help. She intended to finish her book of proofs and go to a place where proofs do not matter because love once done does not undo. But he asked, and she is susceptible to questions asked without swagger. At first she tells herself she is merely aligning her routes to his. Then she stops telling herself anything and listens for new sounds.

There is one: a tutting in the fog that does not belong to her. It is the sound a mother makes when she recognises crumbs in her best bed. It comes from corners. It is not the city; it is something that wants to be spared the trouble of learning streets by taste. It is something that would borrow. That is how she thinks of it, not as a hunter, not as a killer, but as a borrower who returns things wrong-side-out if it returns them at all. The first night she hears it she gentles her large hands as if to hold it; the fog makes room for her and the room does not contain it.

There are stories now that have learned to travel without bodies. Lorna brings them to the back door with the bin bags and the lemon rinds. A boy said he heard his own voice on his phone by the canal, and he answered himself and agreed to meet to return a jacket he had not lost. A taxi driver swears that his last fare vanished while the lights were at red, which is not physically possible and so must be administrative. A girl with a tattoo of an anchor on her forearm said she had kissed a boy who tasted like photographs; she could not explain what flavour that was except that it made her teeth ache in a way she did not dislike. None of the stories are helpful until they are, and that is the problem with stories: they welcome you in and then they make you look at your watch and realise the dark has moved closer.

Mr Cook goes to the canal because stories like water. He stands in the gap between buildings where the wind becomes interested in scarves. He spends twenty minutes making small talk with a crow that is not invested. He watches a student rehearsing being unbothered by the cold by leaving his jacket open and looking at his phone in a way that says the phone is the heat source for his illusion. He sees, finally, what he did not know he was hoping to see; it is a man in a coat with the wrong shoulders.

The shoulders are not wrong in shape. They are wrong in understanding: the coat has been taught the meaning of shoulders by someone who has seen a picture of shoulders, perhaps drawn by a child, and the coat has studied it and passed the test and failed the practice. The hands holding the phone are fine; the hands cut the air like knives cutting air. The shoes, though. The shoes are the problem and the proof. They are black and plain and new and they are left and left. Both left. The gait is a stitch undone every step; the weight lands not heel-to-toe but heel-to-question-mark and you can see the mud trying to be polite about it and failing, flinging up its cheeks to avoid being trodden on by a riddle.

He does not follow because following has its glamour and its disaster and he would prefer to keep his disaster domestic. He lets the wrong-shouldered coat go, and he watches the student watching his phone begin to tilt his head as if he is hearing his name spoken at a distance in the voice of, perhaps, someone who once told him not to go out without a hat. Mr Cook moves then, very quickly. He is not strong and he is not violent, but he is precise and he is in the habit of interrupting. He walks directly up to the student and says, with a voice he uses when a plate is about to fall, that the jacket is not at the bridge. The student blinks, and because youth is the most superstitious thing going he believes what he has been told because it was told with confidence. He shrugs, rude by accident, and goes back indoors.

Mr Cook turns his head to see if the wrong-shouldered coat has turned its head. It has. The face is a face, entirely credible, the face of someone you would not describe if you were trying to describe the face of someone you would not remember. The mouth is wrong. Not visibly. Visibly it is perfect, as if chosen from a list that began with “convincing” and ended with “no query.” But the tongue is unused to lying behind those teeth. His father had had a speech impediment that was not a stammer and not a lisp and was simply a relationship with consonants that required negotiation. This mouth has none of that. It has nothing. It is a mouth that arrived with instructions written in a handwriting nobody could read. It is suddenly, to Mr Cook, impossibly sad.

He goes home quickly, as if somebody were trying to catch up with him and might, if he slowed, ask him his name and he might tell them. He feeds his plants which do not require feeding but appreciate the theatre. He opens the drawer where the photographs live and counts them although he knows exactly how many there are. One is missing. He is not given to melodrama and he is at home and he is not admitting that the room is smaller than it was when he left it, but he shouts anyway, a wordless thing that is the sound he makes when a stack of plates goes and his body moves before his pride. He checks the floor, the radiator edge, the gap behind the bookshelf where crumbs go to plan their future. It is gone. The photograph of Aidan, Fountainbridge, likes sugar has removed itself like a card from a deck a magician has taught to think.

He thinks of calling Lorna because what is friendship if not calling someone when your photographs are escaping. He does not. He thinks of calling Victorine and cannot because he does not have a number or a way of speaking; he has fog and a river and a bench and weather. He goes to the bench. That night it rains in a committed fashion and he refuses to be impressed by it. His coat is not good enough for this sort of romance and he is wet the way a towel is wet after a hotel tries to persuade you that towels can be thin and loyal.

Victorine arrives as if the rain were being generous for once and had decided to drape itself around her. He tells her about the photograph without drama because he has expended his drama on the floor looking for paper. She listens with the attention of someone reading a telegram the war wrote. She says, very quietly, that her pictures do not leave without her permission. He says that the city has never been good at permission. She kneels like a saint with terrible knees and reaches a hand into the bag at her belt and the bag reaches back, a little. She draws out the photograph he lost. It is heavier. It has a dampness around the edges that is not rain.

“Where,” he asks, less startled than he would have been last week. “Where did it go.”

“Someone wanted to see if the page could be turned backwards,” she says. She cradles the square like bread. “I think it learned the beginning of a trick. I think the trick will be dangerous when it has practiced.”

He hates thinking about tricks when what he wants is to think about soup. There is no soup. There is fog and this woman and a river that behaves like an archive. He asks her if she has seen the wrong shoes. She nods with the same patience she uses when a boy bites his mouth and makes a little crescent that will be beautiful when it heals. She has. She sees them most on the edges of bridges. She has watched them stop as if choosing which names to taste next. They interest her in the way a wasp that will not leave the kitchen interests you if you are someone who refuses to close the window on principle.

They make a plan of the sort that will make people who want plans laugh. It involves chalk stolen from a pub quiz where the quizmaster uses it to draw pictures when the questions grow tired. It involves sugar, because Aidan likes sugar and the city has opinions about lure. It involves a fox, because of course it involves a fox. The chalk is for the stones by the bridge. The sugar is poured into a little drift near one of the lamp-posts that has learned to be kind. The fox has not signed anything, but Mr Cook has a relationship with a fox who knows his whistle and will come and take bread from his hand with the quick gentleness of someone who has learned to take quick, gentle things while the engines of the city are leaving.

They arrange the chalk into careless markings and then into careful ones disguised as careless ones. Victorine hums to the lamp-post and asks it to make its light a little warmer, just for an hour, and it agrees because it is flattered that someone has remembered to ask. The sugar waits. The fox also waits, which is not like a fox and suggests that the fox is not waiting for sugar, but for a story. Mr Cook hides, which is not like him, and is good practice for being something other than a waiter.

The wrong-shouldered coat comes the way a rumour comes when it is tired of being so light and would like to see what it feels like to be a body. It stops exactly where they thought. It breathes in, and you can see it take the breath seriously, as if breaths were money you had to account for. It speaks into the student night without opening its mouth. It speaks like an app that is ashamed of itself. It says a name that is not Mr Cook’s. It says, Finn. It says, Finn, did you leave your card. It says it in a voice that is trying to be an apology and failing because it has not learned regret with any of the correct muscles.

The fox moves first. It pads to the sugar, pretends to be greedier than it is, and then sneezes, a small explosion like a cartoon that has chosen to be elegant. The sneeze does what a sneeze does: it removes illusions by forcing a pause. The wrong-shouldered coat turns further than a person turns, as if joints were a story rather than a law. It shows its shoes to the chalk. That is the point. The chalk records without being interested. The chalk writes down the way the weight moves, heel-spiral, heel-spiral, the way the left-left shoes make the gait into a harvest of mistakes. Victorine holds her patient breath and Mr Cook holds his and the city cannot, in fairness, hold its because it has too many lungs between it and the sea. The coat looks at the sugar and then not at the sugar, because there is a precision in the way it rejects human lure and it will not be tricked into sweetness. Mr Cook learns something he does not want: that what wants them does not want them because they are delicious, but because they are impossible.

He does not jump out. He does not reveal anything. He stands very still and lets the chalk do what chalk does. He sees the print of a sole that is brand-new and wrong. He sees, pressed into the heavy white, a pattern that is not a pattern: the heel bears letters, but the letters are nonsense. The letters say NO HAND. The letters are an instruction like the ones on packaging. He thinks, absurdly, of his towels: open the same way, like books ready at the library. He wonders if perhaps there is a library where this thing learned to be with us, and if the books were not alphabetised.

They do not catch it. They do not even get close. It slides away like a memo withdrawn before it can be pinned to a board. It does not mind that it has been observed because observation is not the same as interference and in the city you can die of being observed. They let it go. They keep the chalk, which is not nothing, and the way the light coloured the sugar for a second as if it were gold someone had dropped accidentally. Mr Cook kneels and touches one of the NO HAND letters. His finger is white for a bit and then the rain lifts it and returns him.

Victorine retrieves from her belt a photograph that is not hers and not his. It is a mouth he does not know and a mole that is very exactly placed like a punctuation mark with perfect meaning. She says the name that belongs to it because the name is written on the back and the writing is someone else’s; it is Kellan’s brother’s writing. The photograph had sat in a wallet. She did not steal it. It found its way to her because paper learns the shortcuts grief opens. She gives the picture to Mr Cook not because it will help but because sometimes you give the thing you cannot carry to someone who has volunteered to carry. He takes it like bread. He feels his life actively changing its hinge.

Lorna finds the placemat map because she is the kind of person who is chosen by drawer handles that jam and require a particular wrist to coax them. She is halfway through telling Mr Cook a story about a woman who ate half a lemon tart with her eyes closed because she wanted to prove to someone that she could feel pleasure without needing to locate it, when she sees the map. She stops and kneels and reads. She does not laugh. She says, Oh lamb, which is something she has not called him since the day he told her that he could not be the person other people needed him to be at breakfast. She folds the placemat carefully along the lines of the Water of Leith and tucks it into her bag without asking. He says nothing because consent has already been managed between them in a thousand small ways. She is in. He did not invite her because he is bad at inviting help; she is not waiting for his good behaviour.

Her contribution is immediate and unappreciated by the part of Mr Cook that would like to be in charge. She goes to the places he cannot go because he is not a woman who can be angry in a way that opens doors. She asks bartenders and taxi drivers questions a woman asks when she is a friend of a friend’s sister and she has a photograph and the photograph has light that tells the truth about who will miss a boy. She learns something Mr Cook could not have learned because men lie to men about fear and they tell women the truth in order to be allowed to continue to think of themselves as decent. She learns that a boy who hated olives disappeared near a bin that smelled of olives because the restaurant had put them out with the coffee grounds. She learns that there is someone who calls himself a promoter who promotes nothing; he stands outside clubs and asks for names and pretends to know everyone. He wears scarves to summer events and in winter he tries being serious. He is not the wrong-shouldered coat. He is a different, older wrongness, and she flicks him away like a coat made of a wish that never came true.

Victorine watches all this with a complicated affection that she is careful not to show. She has been told her whole life not to be too much of anything; she is the definition of too much and she is the opposite of it. She comes when called by whistles, by changes in pressure, by a boy’s mother sitting on a doorstep and finally letting a sound out that had been in her for twenty-four years and needed a witness. She does not take pictures of mothers. She takes pictures of boys. She tells herself it keeps the scale right because otherwise she would be too moved and break her own camera with her hands. Sometimes, at night, alone on a roof where the city reminds itself it has vertebrae, she holds one of the squares to her cheek and the cheek remembers the temperature it is missing.

She had a childhood, which is not obvious, and it is relevant now apparently because she cannot stop thinking of the man she loved when she was a size you would call manageable. His name is not for here, as before, but he had a mouth like a comma. He would begin and then pause and then finish and she had loved that about him because she had thought it meant he was thinking, and perhaps it did. He had been taken from the world not by any of the dramatic things that make stories easier to tell; he had been taken by a sequence of small errors nobody owned. She is making a book of lips because someone somewhere had to own something about it and she, it turned out, had hands big enough to hold the blame without it piercing the skin.

The city remains itself and then more itself. It has always had a taste for repetition and now it repeats warnings in new fonts. Someone writes on a wall with chalk that says Do Not Answer Your Name After Midnight. Someone else writes underneath, Unless You Are Hungry, and someone else crosses that out and writes Unless You Are Very Hungry, and someone else writes Unless It Is Your Mother, and beneath it, If It Is Your Mother Make Her Prove It By Telling You a Secret Only Your Dentist Knows. Someone adds, Teeth, and underlines it twice with a flourish that suggests a person in love with solutions. It is funny until it is not. It is not the sort of funny that warms. It is the other kind.

Mr Cook has to work, and there is a Saturday that behaves like a pizza oven. He is very good. He is extraordinary. He moves like a song about knives that is not threatening, just informative. He looks at mouths constantly. It is a problem. He spills nothing, which is suspicious. He asks too many questions and nobody minds because he does it with the generosity that makes you forget the shape of the question and remember only that you enjoyed answering. A table of four boys are celebrating a birthday and pretending not to. He watches them blow out a candle in a way that makes the air think about staying. He watches them put on their coats and choose the order in which to check their pockets for keys, phones, pride.

When they leave he breaks his rule and follows them at a professional distance. He hates himself for it because it feels like surveillance and he is a waiter not a policeman and the word policeman tastes like a spoon in a chipped cup. He walks on the other side of the street. He listens. He hears, astonishingly, the city trying to help. A bus coughs exactly when one of the boys says his own name. A siren runs past at the moment the boy repeats it. The sound covers the slip. The boys do not notice. He thinks of sending the bus a letter. He thinks that perhaps the city is on their side for now because it likes a hunt when it has time for one.

In the moment he most dislikes the man he has become, one of the boys turns and looks right at him and says, You all right, mate, in a kindness he did not expect. He likes the boy’s mouth because it is the shape of a mouth that has just learned how to say sorry and also how to mean thank you so much. He is not a thief, so he lets them go. He walks in the opposite direction and is punished immediately by stumbling into a small crowd that has arranged itself around a guitarist doing something with his thumb that should be illegal. He tries to pass. The guitarist sings a name that is not Mr Cook’s and is and always will be, and for a second there is a heat in the back of his eyes that is either grief or the first great love of his life arriving late and furious. He stands his ground. He puts his hands in his pockets and counts his coins and his breath, one, two, three, four. The song misses its chance.

The chalk prints by the bridge survive one more rain and then are gone, but Mr Cook has them, because of course he does. He has them because Lorna, who is tired of everyone's tendencies towards metaphor when what is needed is an action that can be ticked off, pressed a sheet of brown butcher's paper down hard and peeled it up slow so that the chalk came with it like a bruised sky. The letters NO HAND transferred themselves as if they were bored where they were and fancied travel. She pins the paper to the back of her bedroom door and tells her cousin that it is a mood board. Her cousin believes her because her cousin is too young to have learned to doubt doors.

There is a day when the police come to the restaurant, and a day when they do not. On the day they do, they are new-faced and grieved by the thought of bureaucracy. They ask questions and Mr Cook answers all the ones that are sensible and none of the ones that are not because he cannot bear to say aloud that he thinks there is something wearing our lids and trying not to spill while it walks. He gives them coffee on the house and they try not to accept it and fail and he reads their mouths and sees that they are brave in the way that means they are going to get tired too soon. On the day they do not come, he goes to Dean Village and whips his eyes along every second like a jockey on a temperamental horse.

It happens quietly, because that is the signature being used. A boy appears where there was not a boy. He walks as if he is not sure whether he is here by anyone’s permission but his own. He has a mouth Victorine has not yet taken and she feels the absence like a tooth she cannot stop touching with her tongue. He stops at the bridge because that is what boys do at the bridge; they stop and they decide whether to go on or to think and they mistake both for action. Victorine drops to one knee and the cobbles press back a complaint and in that moment the boy looks up, peering into fog he cannot parse, and the wrong-shouldered coat appears behind him with its hands in the wrong pockets. Mr Cook moves in a way that would embarrass him if the only witness were not someone who makes mistakes for a living. He moves between the boy and the coat, a small kindness in a bad corridor.

“Hey,” he says, and he does not recognise his voice as his. It is not the one he uses to comfort people about crème brûlée. It is the one that used to persuade him to get out of bed. “You’ve dropped something,” he lies, because it is the best he can do, and the lie is a thread and threads are not heroic but they hold buttons on shirts when it matters.

The wrong-shouldered coat stops because it likes games. It looks down. The boy looks down. The only thing there is a dead leaf that has adhered to the stone with the tenacity of the complimentary mint that will not leave a cheque. Mr Cook leans and peels it up and hands it to the boy with an expression that says, please go along with this through the grace of our shared humanity. The boy takes the leaf and smiles because the world is still, despite everything, sometimes gentle, and he says thanks, mate. He goes, not quickly, not neatly, but he goes, and the coat tilts its head as if someone has asked it if it believes in a god that is personal. It breathes in and whatever it smells does not satisfy it. It breathes out and it does not make steam.

Victorine does not take the boy’s mouth. She lets it live unproven for later. She looks at Mr Cook and Mr Cook looks at her and he thinks that there are worse partnerships than one between a giant who cannot say small things and a waiter who can make anything sound like an offer rather than an order. He is going to get hurt. She already is. The city, which listens, sets down another layer of fog like kitchen paper under a birdcage and tells itself that it is absorbing something it does not yet understand.

News breaks as if news were an egg in the hands of someone who cannot be bothered to crack it with care. Another boy missing, a photograph of a mouth on a wall that has the caption Do You Know Him and the comments beneath it that say not helpful things in the upward-tilting shapes of online. Mr Cook stops reading the comments. He keeps walking. Lorna starts wearing two scarves, as if colours could be a brace. Victorine takes a picture of a mouth and feels, in the camera’s weight, a shift that is not gravity. She is being followed. Not by wrong shoes; by something more common and more dangerous: consequence.

The thing that borrows has learned something new. It made a call last night to a boy called Jamie, and it used the voice of his grandmother perfectly, and it said, I found your watch and I’ve put it in the blue dish, love, and Jamie laughed and said, Gran, you don’t know how to text, and the voice said, I learned, because it is not proud. Jamie went home at once to check the blue dish because hope is the most obedient of all the animals and his grandmother is dead and he knows it and still the blue dish called to him. He stood in his hall with his bag on his shoulder and his coat half-off and he did not cry because if he cried there would be salt in the room and salt is honest and he is not ready. He slept in his coat on the sofa because sleep is a thing you have to do near the place you thought something would be.

Mr Cook does not know this story yet. He will, because all the small true things get to him eventually. For now he has a placemat map, a photograph with a mole, a sheet of brown paper with shoe letters, two scarves to follow in a crowd, a fox who sneezes on cue, and a giant who hums to light. He has more than he has ever had. He also has the beginning of a dread that does not resemble any of the others he has practiced. He has always feared embarrassment and failure and unkindness and the kind of chaos that lets you think you can fix it until you realise it is sleeping in your bed. This new fear has a quieter appetite. It would like to take everybody’s name out of their mouths and put it somewhere safe where safety is the same as silence.

It is a Tuesday when he realises the thing he should have realised on a Sunday. He is polishing cutlery with a cloth that has lost its patience, and he is listening to the clock refuse to keep up, and he is moving in the spaces between one order and the next, and he hears Lorna call his name and it buzzes his skin in a way it does not usually. He feels the shape of it along his nerves. He looks up and she is smiling because there is a customer who has asked to see the person who made their evening better by being specific about the bread. He thinks, without wanting to, about leaving his name somewhere the wrong-shouldered coat could step on it. He thinks about writing down something that does not last and handing it over and calling it proof. He goes to the table and he is good and he is funny and he is kind and then he is out in the alley breathing and tasting rosemary from the kitchen and the air tastes also of something like new plastic and he understands that the thing he is hunting will try to get him in the way of a gift.

He finds Victorine that night by walking into the old train tunnel where the city keeps its ghosts, and the ghosts do not mind because he steps carefully. He tells her what he understood about gifts. She nods and says that all stories about riddles begin with presents that aren’t. He nods and hates that this is the shape. They are going to have to offer something to take something. They are going to have to put something on the table. He laughs a little, not because it is funny but because he has always liked tables. He says, all right, and hears his own voice like a drawer closing after everything has been put in the wrong place on purpose.

They set it up like a service. They choose a night when the fog has rubbed itself raw against streetlamps. They choose a bridge that has learned to forgive apologies that come too late. They choose a boy who will not be hurt because he does not exist except in the way all of us exist in other people’s stories. They choose a name that belongs to no one because it belongs to too many. They choose Finn because the city has a taste for repetition and they will use it against itself. They do not tell Lorna because she will make it better and safer and they have left themselves no room for better or for safe.

Mr Cook stands where the sugar was and where the chalk was and where the wrong shoulders had been. He wears a scarf Lorna would approve of and shoes that are right and make the right noise. He takes his phone out and places it on the parapet face-up like an offering and he steps back and he waits. He does not call. He does not say his name. He makes himself into an answer. It is not wise. It is the only thing that makes any sense to him, and sense is a thing he trusts when he does not trust good sense.

Victorine becomes a building. She stands inside the fog like a keel and the fog obliges and drapes itself. She holds her camera with her finger on the lip of it as if she were about to say shh. The fox waits in the hedge pretending to be a hedge. The city attends, not for them, but because this is a thing it knows how to do: it can be an audience for need. The wrong-shouldered coat comes as if it has been invited by a letter written in a hand that has practiced for hours and still gets its capital Ks wrong and is proud of that. It reaches for the phone. It does not aim to take it. It aims to learn it. It aims to taste what it means to put your face near a small metal lake and wait for your reflection to say yes.

Victorine moves and the camera does something it was not designed to do and could not do in any other hands; it inhales. The square inside it hungry to become is hungry earlier than it is given permission to be. The picture takes the shape of the wrongness and the wrongness dislikes being made into paper. It pulls away. It leaves behind, as all frightened things do, a piece of itself that can be put in a pocket. It is small and it is soft and it is a thin black ribbon that smells of wet cardboard and of someone else’s breath. Mr Cook does not touch it because he has learned a lot of things very quickly, and one of them is that you do not put your hands in bags that are waiting to find out what they are.

Victorine does not pick the ribbon up. She looks at it as if it had prayed and she is not the right goddess. She hums. It hums back in a frequency made of needles. The fox sneezes and ruins the seriousness. Mr Cook laughs because if he does not laugh he will have to make a sound he is not ready to own. The wrong-shouldered coat is gone in the way you learn to be gone when someone has taken your copy and you are not sure which world the copy will be truer in. The phone on the parapet lights up because it has been watching like a child under a blanket and wishes to be in the conversation.

They do not win. They arrange, instead, a very small defeat for an enemy who cannot be certain yet that it can be defeated at all. They do not bless themselves because they have different religions, both of which are mostly about not getting in the way of what is beautiful. They pick up the ribbon with a fork, because there are rules, and they take it to the restaurant kitchen and place it in a stainless steel bowl that has heard confessions. The ribbon tastes like a lie you told in Year Eight that adjusted your life just enough that you cannot get back to the other you. They watch it for an hour. It does nothing you can see. It is trying to learn a phone number.

After, Mr Cook walks Lorna home along a road they have named between them because naming roads keeps them honest. He does not tell her about the ribbon yet. He tells her a different truth in exchange, which is that he is tired of not being the first person at any table that matters. She says, old news, and she is so kind with it that he nearly stops to put his head against her shoulder. He does not. He keeps walking because if he stops now he will have to examine the ribbon in the bowl and decide whether he has become a scientist or a thief or a priest and he does not want to be any of those things before a late night service.

At home, he opens the drawer with the photographs and counts again and touches the edges and informs them that he is not their father. He tells them they are visiting. He tells them they can stay as long as they remember that they are guests and that he will put them out with the recycling if they begin to lie. He is ridiculous. The pictures are paper. He tells himself that after all of this is over he will sell everything he owns that can hold a reflection and live like a monk except for the radio. He will never do that. He loves radios. He will buy another one. He will place it on the counter among the spoons and tell it news he has partly invented so it can play him music he did not know he needed.

Victorine crosses the city with the ribbon in her camera and the camera heavier because it is keeping a thing it does not like. She climbs the Scott Monument at dawn and pretends she is not. The stone notices and approves the effort. She stands where men with hats once decided to be brave in a way that involved being rude to people who wrote with their left hands. She unwraps the ribbon and lets the wind smell it. The wind is excellent at naming things, better than any god. It is the first to tell her the word she has been avoiding because to have a name is a blessing and a risk. It says, Borrower, and then it says, Not Exactly, and then it invents a word that cannot be spelled in human alphabets because it requires a letter that looks like a door you can walk through only once. She accepts the failure. She hates to fail. She holds the ribbon in the air and says, quietly, the name she never says and the love that made her big bends through the morning like someone taking a shortcut through a field.

The ribbon flutters. It has learned one thing. It has learned that if it says a name with enough sincerity, doors will open the size of mouths. It says Victorine. It says it perfectly, on the first try, with the exact weight her mother gave it and the exact tilt her lover used when he had seen something he enjoyed about it. She almost drops the ribbon, not because she is frightened of it, but because she is frightened of the exactness of her own longing. She puts it away. She decides not to die today of being understood by the wrong thing.

In the afternoon the sky lies flat on the city like someone resting their face on a cool table. Messages travel; the wrong ones are popular. The posters with the mouths fade. Mr Cook takes them down and puts them up again and takes them down and puts them up again because destroying and saving are how we pass the time before the solution. He can feel, in his bones that were his mother’s shoulders on his father’s frame, the moment approaching when they will have to cease harm reduction and commit a harm. He does not know what it will be. He does not know if it will be the wrong one. He suspects he will do it anyway and apologise to the air later the way he apologises to tables he bumps into.

By the river, a boy with a scar above his mouth that looks like a moon stands and waits. He is not Kellan. He is not anyone they know yet. A fox carries bread as if it were a bag full of money and looks at him in a way that suggests that this time the fox is the emissary and the boy is the message. Victorine watches from a place that cannot be a place and Mr Cook reads the menus of the night and orders something small and sharp and costly. He cannot keep a line in his head to save it. He keeps the whole city instead, because sometimes the big thing is easier to hold than the small. The fog returns and sighs and arranges its face into a new expression. The game has learned itself. The stakes are small and human and the city is going to make itself smaller to fit them. The camera hums. The chalk waits for its next life. The ribbon dreams of keys. The door the wind named shifts a fraction in a hinge nobody can see.Morning does not so much arrive as decide to be generous with visibility, and Mr Cook stands in the quiet restaurant with the radio speaking its lettered weather like a priest of tides. He polishes glasses with a cloth that knows his hands and listens to the litany — Viking, North Utsire, South Utsire — and thinks that perhaps the sea would understand a thing that calls you by your name and expects the obedience of boats. He has put the stainless steel bowl under a shelf where it will hear the radio but not see the door, because sight is a luxury and listening is work. Inside the bowl the thin black ribbon behaves itself the way children behave when they have plans that require nobody to watch them. He taps the rim of the bowl the way one taps a sleeping cat, light and apologetic, and the ribbon does not move, but he feels, along the bones that run like a sentence down his forearms, the moment a number fails to reach the person who wanted it.

Lorna arrives carrying a bag that clucks with knitting needles and indignation. She has tied one of her scarves in a way that makes the colours listen to one another rather than fight, and he sees that there are small stitches near the ends where a person with patience has embroidered letters that could be names if you wanted them to be, or could be rivers, if you were the sort of person who declined to be specific in case specificity made you vulnerable. She says nothing about the bowl because she has told herself that she will be told, and he sees the restraint and loves her for it in the precise way you love a person who knows that what you are doing is too much and refuses to say the sentence that begins with stop. She goes into the bar and rearranges thirty glasses by one-quarter inch because there is safety at that scale and then she leans on the counter and says, conversationally, that her cousin’s boyfriend’s pal knows a man who was asked last week for two left shoes.

The cobbler in Stockbridge wears magnifying lenses that make his eyes serious as clocks. He works in a narrow room that has the atmosphere of somebody who solved a great problem once and would like to be asked how. He passes the butcher’s brown paper print through his hands in a way that does not smudge the chalk and smiles a small private smile at the letters. NO HAND, he says it like a blessing that got its pronunciation wrong, and explains that certain manufacturers stamp their cartons with warnings intended for forklifts and human wrists, NO HAND TRUCK, NO HAND FEED, NO HAND HERE, and that sometimes glue is impatient and marries rubber when no one is watching. He says he has seen shoes mispaired because people mispair and that he does not believe in curses, which is what people say when they have a drawer full of countercurses labelled lace ends. He saw a man two weeks ago bring in a pair of black trainers and ask for both to be altered, both left, both to match, and the man had shoulders that did not introduce themselves properly to their coat. He remembers this not because the man was odd, but because the man tipped badly, and the cobbler keeps his lists with the same fidelity he uses with soles.

They walk out into a brightness that makes the pavements confess their stains, and Lorna, who has come because she insisted on coming, says that the cobbler smelled like almonds and worry. Mr Cook carries the butcher’s paper like a hymn and thinks that this, this little piece, could be enough to thread into the city and pull. Victorine does not come into the shop because she has learned that even in a city that acts like an auntie, the sight of a woman who has been threaded by love into too much is a problem for ceilings. She waits around the corner with a fox that has the lack of manners of a creature that has never made a booking and watches people walk past her coat as if it were a ship’s sail drying, which is, in the most literal sense, true. The ribbon inside her camera has behaved since dawn with a politeness that worries her, because politeness in wrong things often signals calculus.

They follow the cobbler’s memory as if it were a string tied to a tin can two children speak into. The string leads to a place that calls itself a warehouse because the city will forgive a person anything except pretension, and inside the warehouse are boxes that believe they will be asked to live again as wardrobes and tables and not as coffins for whatever the night has been doing. The manager wears keys that hit one another like a friendly argument when he moves and tells Lorna that yes, they do receive consignments of shoes in bulk, no, they do not sell pairs, yes, sometimes film people come and buy six lefts for a shot they are lying about, no, he does not ask questions because the warehouse is a church of second chances and the offertory bowl does not interrogate the hands. Lorna flirts with a shelf the way she flirts with anyone who could give her answers, and the shelf does not hold out, but the clipboard on a hook near the door does, because paper loves betrayal. There is an order, dated wrong because someone typed with a finger that thought yesterday was today, for twelve left black trainers, size nine, for a production whose name is borrowed from a poem and therefore not trustworthy.

Victorine’s names do not like buildings like this. They curl back inside her chest when she steps through and bloom again when she steps out, as if air that has been kept too long under a roof has lost the quality that lets names ride it without complaint. She hates this room without blaming it; it is a hoarder of the things the night has lost and she is enough of a night to recognise kin. The ribbon in her camera lifts itself like a hair that has decided to notice static, and, very gently, she presses the heel of her thumb against the lip of the lens and says, as if to a child, that they are not doing this here because not every fight needs an audience that would pay the wrong sort of attention. The ribbon flattens and pretends to be well again.

In Morningside there is a woman whose students used to call her Miss Sing and whose neighbours call her June because June is the name you choose if you plan to offer lemonade on days that become themselves. She taught choirs how to turn the wheel of air into sound without fraying their throats and how to carry their names to the back row of halls without spilling them on the way. Victorine thinks of her suddenly when the ribbon says her own name and she hears, in the exactitude, the ache of potential misuse. They go to June’s door because you must collect experts even if your expertise is grief. June opens before they knock because she is conducting her kettle and knows when to drop a bar. She looks at Victorine with a satisfaction you feel when a myth keeps an appointment and at Mr Cook with a kindness that belongs to people who feed people. She does not ask them to sit, because talk sitting is the wrong shape for what they have brought, and she says, in a voice that has not forgotten how to stand, that there are three ways to avoid answering to the wrong call and none of them is cowardice.

The first is to choose a name that is too heavy to be lifted by anything but love, which is why men in uniform say their last names and lovers say anything but. The second is to carry a hum in your mouth so that when strangers put their fingers in the latch and try to open you, they find the house already singing its own music and get bored. The third is to borrow a name you can afford to lose and wear it like a coat you expect rain for. June says all of this while slicing bread as if the slice were the rest note between chorus and verse, and Mr Cook hates that the answer is both actual and impractical. He tells her that the boys already hum because music is the thing that turned into breath and back again every Saturday for ten years. June nods, because she has seen boys lean their faces over scores with expressions like cliff-edges, and she goes to her dresser and removes a box of old badges from a time when badges were ways to identify yourself to each other and not to authority. She gives them three, each stamped with a word that is not a name and therefore can be spent safely. Mr Cook’s says Always, because he is, and Lorna’s says Loud, because she is, and Victorine’s says Gentle, because it is the thing she is whenever anybody allows her the space.

They leave June with the promise of cake when this is over and walk out into a day that is pretending to be simple by being complicated in the small ways and Mr Cook tries the badge on and hears in his chest a shift that is not magic but is something like posture. At a corner he pauses because his phone has had an idea about ringing. He looks at the screen and sees his first name there like a tooth he does not touch and feels a jealousy for it he cannot defend. He has not given it to anyone for months. He does not answer. He stands and breathes through the urge to be polite to wrong numbers and the screen stops shouting with the grace of something that has not yet learned persistence.

Night is how the city admits it has opinions, and that night the opinions concern bridges. North Bridge is tired of being dramatic; South Bridge would like to be acknowledged for its usefulness; the little bridges had decided the word is causeway. They go back to the place where chalk remembered letters and sugar pretended to be a trap. Lorna carries a bag that would get her arrested if anyone looked into it without context and Mr Cook carries context, which is to say explanations, which he intends to use only if it becomes necessary to be forgiven by someone in a hat. Victorine carries her camera with the strap against her neck in a way that makes it look light and is a lie. They have a plan that could be described as amateur if amateur came from love and the will to offer rather than command. It involves June’s hum and a piece of butcher’s paper and the knowledge of where men stop to be a little daft before they find home.

At eleven, the ribbon makes an attempt. It lifts its end within the camera as if greeting a host who has learned to cook one dish well. Victorine closes her hand around the camera’s belly and says, No, and if you have never heard a woman who is allowed to be that large say No, you cannot know how tender a refusal can be and still strip paint. The ribbon droops like ivy that has discovered the wall is temporary. Mr Cook blows into his cupped hands because superstition and cold are equal co-authors, and Lorna ties a scarf around his throat and tucks into it the bottom edges of his jaw with the decisiveness of somebody wrapping a wound. They wait. They are very good at waiting now, which is not universally to be celebrated.

It appears not in the wrong coat but in a better one. The shoulders have done their homework. The shoes have learned to apologise for themselves by scuffing where scuffs should be and Mira down the row of tenements has left her radio on just enough that it can admit there is such a thing as jazz. What gives it away is the way it looks at the river and cannot read it. People who have lived here, even for a season, can read the black of the Water of Leith the way you read a menu — knowing where the prices are and where the small print hides. This thing looks and sees only a straight line you could step over if you were allowed to step. It speaks into the fog and the fog rolls like a cat saying perhaps. It says a name. It says Michael, in a voice that would make you hand a person your wallet and your summer if you were twenty-two and the last text you sent said where are you.

June taught them the hum, and the hum is not a tune, it is a continuousness, a vowel you choose for its roundness and its stubbornness, and Mr Cook takes it into his mouth and puts it against his teeth like a coin to check its metal and then he hums and Lorna hums and Victorine hums and the bridge takes the hum and passes it along and the fox yawns because the fox is a critic. The name Michael does not find a latch to lift. The coat waits as if patience were a religion it is trying out because it wants somewhere to sit. The ribbon behaves. The camera breathes through its own lungs for once. Mr Cook feels the hum as work and work is his faith and he keeps it going and feels the way the name slides off like rain made and failed.

It changes tactics because that is the particular intelligence of things that borrow; they change without growing.
