What gives it away is the way it looks at the river and cannot read it. People who have lived here, even for a season, can read the black of the Water of Leith the way you read a menu — knowing where the prices are and where the small print hides. This thing looks and sees only a straight line you could step over if you were allowed to step. It speaks into the fog and the fog rolls like a cat saying perhaps. It says a name. It says Michael, in a voice that would make you hand a person your wallet and your summer if you were twenty-two and the last text you sent said where are you.

June taught them the hum, and the hum is not a tune, it is a continuousness, a vowel you choose for its roundness and its stubbornness, and Mr Cook takes it into his mouth and puts it against his teeth like a coin to check its metal and then he hums and Lorna hums and Victorine hums and the bridge takes the hum and passes it along and the fox yawns because the fox is a critic. The name Michael does not find a latch to lift. The coat waits as if patience were a religion it is trying out because it wants somewhere to sit. The ribbon behaves. The camera breathes through its own lungs for once. Mr Cook feels the hum as work and work is his faith and he keeps it going and feels the way the name slides off like rain made and failed.

It changes tactics because that is the particular intelligence of things that borrow; they change without growing. It speaks not into the fog but into the phone in Mr Cook’s pocket, or rather into the air that phones arrange around themselves like a small arena. He feels the vibration in his coat and he does not move because movement is how you admit the call belongs to you, and he hums louder and the city hums back because buses make that noise when they leave you anyway, and the wrong-shouldered coat is suddenly less elegant. It steps forward in a way you would call decided if you were in a meeting, and Lorna steps in front of Mr Cook because habit is not hierarchy. She says a word that is not a name. She says Enough, and the coat falters because you cannot persuade a table to hold more plates than it has legs for and you cannot pull more names out of a mouth than it has space. The fox sneezes with exquisite timing and if this were a play you would accuse the director of cheapness but it is life so you accept it as an angel.

Victorine lifts the camera and lets it inhale, and the inhalation is careful, and the square that comes into being is not of a mouth but of the line between the wrong shoulder and the wrong sense of gravity. It slides out slowly, shy for once, and she presses her thumb to it and feels beneath the gloss the whirring of something that does not enjoy being turned into a square. The coat retreats with the dignity of a person who will write an email later and CC everyone, and they do not chase it because chasing is plot and plots are for people who enjoy being in danger in a manner that can be summarised in five sentences for friends later. The new square dries with the reluctance of a child putting on a jumper and when she holds it to the light you can see, unmistakably, the edge of a foot and the imprint NO HAND in mirror and upside down but faithful.

They do not win, not exactly, but they lift a thread and knot it where it cannot be pulled without something else loosening. They go back to the restaurant and put the new picture on the steel beside the ribbon and they watch the two of them be near without acknowledging each other, the way two cousins do who have been seated together at a wedding and have decided on a truce until speeches are done. Mr Cook listens to the radio and lets his name be a rock at the bottom of running water. Lorna pours salt into the bowl in a ring not because she believes in salt but because believing in salt is a good use of hands. Victorine leans her head against the refrigerator door and closes her eyes, and because she is very tired, the world shifts an inch to make that not hurt.

The notices go up on more boards and the city invents new ways to avoid saying itself. Bus drivers switch to numbers and whistles. The bar in Tollcross calls last orders by raising a green cloth instead of a voice. People pin badges to their coats that say words that make no sense out loud because sense is edible. June’s choir returns, not as a choir, but as thirty separate people who know how to stand and breathe and they become, over a week, a line of humming that runs along every bridge at night. It is ridiculous and beautiful, and if you are cynical about beautiful ridiculousness you should be careful not to live near the sea because the sea is not interested in you.

There is a small success which would not be reported by any paper with the courage to call itself a paper: a boy called Jamie wakes at two because his phone lit up the sofa where he fell asleep with his coat on and he hears his grandmother say, love, the watch, and he gets as far as the hall where the blue dish waits because dishes are patient and he stops because in his mouth is a ribbon of hum that he did not intend and that has been lent to him by men he has not met and women he would be frightened of and a fox who sneezed for comedy. He stands there and does not answer and his phone gives up because it is not brave, it is a phone, and he goes back to the sofa and puts his hand in his coat pocket and finds the watch he had thought was lost and cries a little, only a little, because he is twenty and tears embarrass him still and he will come here later, with flowers, to the table where this was planned, and he will not say thank you because he will not know, and that is the correct kind of magic.

It cannot last. If you have ever held a pattern in place for an hour you will know that hour costs a day. They wake a sleeping thing that is not the Borrower Not Exactly but the part of the city that disapproves of volunteer projects. A policeman with a young face and a boss with an older voice comes to the restaurant and asks for them to stop humming at bridges because it is creating a nuisance, bicycles cannot pass safely, someone is going to fall in and then where will we be. Lorna makes tea and puts it in front of them with the gentleness she keeps for the kind of argument that can be won without anyone losing their pride, and Victorine sits very still because one of the men is afraid of heights and she is higher than his nervous system will allow for. Mr Cook uses his voice in the way he uses a napkin, to wipe away the part of the mess that can be wiped, and tells the young policeman that the humming will move to the Meadows for a week because variety is good for lungs and he will write a letter about railings on bridges because nothing deters the part of danger that is boredom like ironwork.

Lorna sees it first because she was always going to: the picture of Kellan’s scar, the one like a thumbprint of the moon above his lip, is fading at its left edge. It is not water damage. It is the precise slow removal of a margin, as if someone were gently recalling consent. She tells Mr Cook without the part where she would like to swear and he holds the picture as if he were holding the edge of a chipped plate which will shatter if you put it down wrong and then you will have to say you were the person who did that. They watch the silver of the paper try to become blank and they ask themselves, out loud and then quiet, what in the name of every ridiculous saint that forgives the ridiculous is happening. Victorine presses the picture to her cheek and then to the part of the camera that could be called its heart, and then she does the thing she seldom does which is to ask for help without making it sound like a proposition. She looks at the ceiling, which is a way of looking at the city inside, and says, please.

The city does not answer in words because words are expensive when you are that old. It answers in arrangement. The lights discriminate not at all and then exactly, making a spill here and a shadow there. The oven decides to be honest about its temperature. The radio chooses the shipping forecast again, and this time the voice is not wrong and not right, but careful. In that care they hear the place to go. It is not written on a map that admits it is a map, but Mr Cook already has a map that makes no apologies for being made out of a placemat. It points his finger to Leith, where the water can be touched without trespass, and to a warehouse that is not the one with the keys but the one made of brick that thinks it is a ship. Lorna says she is coming and he says of course and neither of them looks at Victorine because they are not noble; they are practical, and noble people die because they were busy being noble at the wrong moment.

They take bolt cutters because Lorna has a cradle of cousins at her disposal and one of them loves to know he is needed. They take a torch and then another, because the first will fail at the moment narrative requires it, and they take biscuits because Lorna is not stupid. The fox goes with them because it has decided this is the troupe it belongs to now and someone has to be in charge of stealing eggs when they return triumphant and hungry. Victorine goes by the high roads because her shadow is a currency she is not willing to spend near police vans, and she tells the city in her big kind way that they are not breaking; they are opening. The city, which has made worse puns, allows it.

The warehouse smells of rope that has retired unwillingly and of oil that has decided it would rather be soap. The door does its job and resists until reason persuades it that drama is inappropriate and then it yields with a civility that suggests it will ask for an apology later. Inside are stacked cages for things that have already had names, and boxes for things that never will, and there is, worse than anything, an arrangement of coats on a pipe that might be shoulders and might be ghosts. Lorna shines the torch and the light makes the coats look as if they have chosen to be seen and this is a decision nobody should have to live with. Mr Cook feels his mouth become a stranger for the second time in a week and checks with his tongue that his teeth are his and finds that they are and that this, too, is a luxury.

They find the radio first because the radio wants to be found; it is tuned to a frequency between music and the hiss fishes make when they are being listened to by something with no skin. It speaks names with the accent of a person learning how to ask for a glass of water in a language not their own, proudly, then with an apology, and Mr Cook steps forward and pulls the plug out with a theatricality he did not know he had, and is bitterly disappointed to find that the sound continues because electricity is not the god here, attention is. He takes the radio and places it in a bag and ties the bag shut because sometimes gesture is the way forward and Lorna reaches up and unties the bag again because she is not sentimental and removes the batteries and pockets them and snaps the bag shut as if she has broken the back of a gnat.

There is a table beneath the pipe of coats. It has a cloth thrown over it that believes this is a dinner party and that the late arrival will be handsome and clever and bear wine as a personality trait. On the table is a bowl. It is blue. It is not a blue that belongs to a shop. It is the blue of that bowl and only that bowl, the one on the radiator in a flat where somebody lived and took off their rings to wash vegetables and placed them in this exact circle and put them back on and carried on not thinking about the fingers that carried them. The bowl is empty. The bowl is reverent. Victorine puts her hand around the outside of it and thinks that if somebody took away every proof of a life but the temperature their bowls remembered, she could reconstruct love and hunger perfectly. Mr Cook does something he will always confess to later as the moment he conceded he was not a person who remained in the shallow end; he touches the inside of the bowl with his fingertip and a temperature answers him, tepid as someone who waited and decided not to be angry about it. He takes the bowl gently and wraps it in Lorna’s scarf and she does not protest because her heart has made room for a shrine.

They do not see the wrong-shouldered coat enter because this time it decides on stairs and it knows where they groan. They hear, instead, a neat cough in the space where men who bring pastries cough to announce delicacy and they turn as one as if they had rehearsed and forgotten and remembered in their bodies. It does not wear a coat now. It has made a decision about shoulders and got closer, alarmingly close, and it is wearing a mouth like a suit that was tailored by a committee. It says, with impeccable social ease, there you are, and it says the name that is never said in this book because it will not last if it is said and will only get the attention it should not have if we write it down. It says the name of the man Victorine loved and in the same breath it says a sound it has no right to which is the small private word that man used when he addressed her from a threshold and she had turned and he had needed to make his wanting lower than the house could hear.

There are times when size does not help. There are times when a woman as tall as a church is as vulnerable as the word thank you. Victorine rocks, just enough for the rope smell to put itself into her. The ribbon flares like a thing that has waited for its cue and then finds the audience also waited, and the camera takes a picture without her asking and she hates this, because consent is the only god she obeys. The picture is hot, actually hot, and she drops it and the square slaps against the cloth on the table and the blue bowl makes a sound like a throat. Mr Cook moves with the speed he reserves for plates that will burn him and scoops the picture up and presses it, burning, to the steel of his own breath and when he looks there is, impossibly, nothing on it. It is a blank that is not blank; it is the most precise white he has ever seen, the white of a room that was scrubbed for inspection, and it makes his eyes smart because it is a lie and an aspiration together.

Lorna speaks because Lorna is someone who speaks and she says, I am not your mother, in a tone she has used on men who assumed, and the coat flickers because it has perhaps been called that before by a person it did not know how to disobey. She steps forward with the bolt cutters in both hands and it does not retreat, it merely rearranges itself as if someone on a train had asked to sit by the window instead. She is a reasonable woman in a bad room and she says, the boys you borrowed, bring them back, and it answers with the kind of smile you have when you have read about smiles and have not yet constructed one from practice. It looks at Victorine and says in the voice of the comma-mouthed man, darling, and she sets the camera down and puts both hands on the table and says, once, his name, and the brick of the warehouse changes, very slightly, from a place to a person. You could feel sorry for the thing, then, because it has stumbled into a family that was bigger than it expected to find.

The air moves. There are words you can do that with. There are names you can do that with. She does not have him, because nobody has the dead back; she has the pressure of a shoulder against a door and what she chooses to do with it is different from what the story would have chosen for her if she had been less large. She does not farm it for power. She uses it as a handle to open a reasonable door. She says to the Borrower Not Exactly, you are trying to be a reply, and somewhere, because the city can never resist applause for precision, a bus makes a contented air sound. The coat ripples. It is not insulted. It is relieved to be told.

They realise something they should have, and will blame themselves for a little later, for not seeing earlier. It is not a hunter. It is the answer that arrives after the echo and it knows only the timing of reply. It makes a call because it is trying to give you what you wanted and its problem is that it cannot tell the difference between a wanted thing and a polite one. It has been taught by warehouses and return policies and the way we address one another online where our mouths are not present to correct us. It has never learned to ask its own question. Victorine looks at it the way you look at a dog who has eaten a glove and still wants to be praised because it is indeed a dog. She says, then ask me something, and it says, obediently and with no art, what is your name.

There are parts of love that are unkind because they make you pay in the right currency and not in the sentimental one. She answers. She gives her name to the wrong thing on purpose so that the right thing, which is the keeping of boys who do not understand that they are delicious, can be moved an inch closer to safety. The camera whines like an animal in a trap because it has been made complicit and objects, and the ribbon writhes and leaps from the bowl to the picture and back and the radio in the bag speaks a letter which is the beginning of a weather and the coats on the pipe shake as if focusing. Mr Cook puts the bowl in his arms as if it were a child he is not officially allowed to hold and he steps back and his heel touches a box marked NO HAND and his ankle twists because it is a body and bodies resent symbolism. Lorna lifts the bolt cutters and slams them down onto the pipe not to cut it but to make a noise the size of a decision and the coats fall. You would be surprised how vocal cloth can be.

The Borrower Not Exactly steps forward and then back, two left feet offering a dance. Victorine says his name again, not the coat’s, the comma-mouthed one, and in the saying she feels the edge of a door the wind told her she would only walk through once and she is suddenly, precisely, the size she would be if she had stayed small and had not loved ridiculously. It lasts only as long as a picture sliding from a mouth; she is herself again with the undertaste of a different gravity. She knows what she can do and what the price will be and she will pay it because the ledgers of women like her do not make sense to anyone who has never been entrusted with a weight that arrives disguised as a present.

They do not defeat it here in the room with the radio and the bowl and the coats that remember shoulders imperfectly, but they change the clock. They teach the wrong-shouldered coat the feel of No as something other than grief. They give it, for the first time, boredom. It does not enjoy it. It slips not away but sideways, which is worse, and they stand in the smell of rope and old oil and do the practical things which are to put the batteries back into the radio, to take photographs of the labels on the boxes, to erase the footprints with a broom because leaving stories for people who did not consent to hear them is rude, to wrap the bowl well, to lock the door badly because the lock is a gesture, not a machine.

Mr Cook carries the blue bowl like a promise and says nothing for a long time because if he says anything it will be the sentence that begins with my name and he has not decided yet whether he will give it to the city at last as a gift or keep it a little longer as a way to survive. Lorna loops her scarf around the bowl and then around his wrist and says, teasing because the alternative is wailing, that he is handcuffed now to a dish and that this is the exact level of kink she thought he would embrace in middle age. He laughs and it does what laughter does; it irons some of the fear flat so they can fold it and put it away for when it is useful. Victorine walks with them a while and then not at all, because fog has need of her elsewhere and her camera is angry and she is not frightened of anger when it is honest.

They go home not through the heart of anything but by the edges where delivery vans clean their teeth on corners and cats have opinions about the night that are only reluctantly shared. In his flat Mr Cook puts the blue bowl on the table and all the useless, holy objects he has collected notice there is now a centre. He places in the bowl his name written on a piece of paper he tears from the margin of his placemat map because it is the only paper that understands him and he folds it once and then again and then he does not fold it a third time. He says to Lorna, who is pretending not to look, that he is not doing magic, he is doing harm reduction, and she says that he can call it what he wants as long as he eats something incapable of answering him back. He eats toast. It is the right level of honesty for bread.

That night, under bridges, the hum is a little higher and the water carries it with less complaint, and at June’s the metronome that sits on her piano, a handsome piece of wood with a pompous face, refuses to tick exactly because some kinds of time are not to be measured so literally. Victorine takes a picture of a mouth that will never need proof because it is attached to a man who talks kindly to his dog and tips his hat to fog. She puts the picture in her belt and the belt creaks like a rueful horse. The ribbon sleeps, if ribbon can do anything so mammalian, and it dreams a number. When it wakes it has learned how to say it. It says the number aloud in the dark room of the restaurant and the stainless steel bowl shudders a little and does not break because it has heard worse.

In the morning there are two new posters on the boards near the chemist. One is the boy with the moon scar and one is not and both have mouths that look like doors, and a woman with a shopping bag reads them as if there were a recipe on them and she might try it tonight with onions. She does not know she is being kept safe by a bridge that hums and a fox that sneezes and a waiter who has tied his life to a bowl and a woman who is too big to be left out of any story that means to finish itself honestly. The city tells itself the long song again and in it there is a new bar, a thin ribbon of melody that knows how to say no without being cruel, and it is as if a new canal had been dug overnight, and fish that wanted to live could find it. The wrong-shouldered coat walks in daylight past a café window and its reflection learns for a second how to lag, and if you were looking you might have put your coffee down and stood and followed it. You would not have caught it. You would have learned, though, the smell it leaves when it is bored, which is printed paper and the skin of milk that everyone complains about and few refuse to eat. You would have understood why May feels like a hat you can only wear in June.

At the restaurant the dishwasher hums with the satisfaction of a job it has decided to love and the clock is still wrong and always will be because some things need to be wrong so you have a reason to keep telling the truth. Mr Cook writes on his placemat map with a biro that is running out and chooses to enjoy the way it insists, with its fading line, that this matters. He knows what they are going to have to do next and he hates it because it will require taking somebody else’s name out of their mouth for an hour and putting something harmless in its place, and he is the sort of man who apologises to tables. He will do it anyway. He will find the kindest way to do it. He will collect a list of apologies and he will give them to the air after the part that hurts, and the air will decide, case by case, whether to return any of them stamped with a pretty mark that says accepted.

Chapter 7 began like a service set before opening, with the light too honest and the air making specific suggestions about what care should look like, and Mr Cook stood with his hands scrubbed rawer than usual, looking at the blue bowl that had become a room inside the room, his folded name sitting there like a small animal that had agreed to be looked after and was trying very hard not to be interesting. The paper had absorbed the bowl’s temperature and given something back, a faint warmth that had nothing to do with radiators and everything to do with attention; he touched the edge of the bowl and felt the soft reticent heat pass into his fingertips and up to his wrists, as if the tendon-strings had become a staff and someone competent were marking time on them. The ribbon in its steel basin had learned to lounge with a studied indifference that set every hair on his arm on edge, and when Victorine came in carrying weather as if it were a shawl she had found at a market and couldn’t leave behind, she set the camera down as one sets down a sleeping child one is worried is faking, and said that the ribbon had said a number in the night, not loudly, not invasively, but with the persistence of a drip in a house you chose because it didn’t have leaks.

It was a number with the rhythm of a duty, not a number with the rhythm of a person, and Lorna, who had a relationship with phones that had nothing to do with fear and everything to do with boundaries, wrote it on her palm with a pen that had been borrowed without permission from the post office and said she would not call it because calling it would be the same as inviting it for tea and offering it cake and then asking it to leave when it had just put its fork down. They did not call. Mr Cook walked his eyes up and down the figures the way a baker checks a recipe that is written in somebody else’s handwriting and noticed, with the mean satisfaction of a person who cannot help but enjoy spotting the seam in a trick, that the number did not have a proper beginning; it had been cut from a longer thing, and in the cutting had been made into a key that would open nothing and everything if you pressed it against the right door. He put his hand to the bowl again and the bowl told him, with the implacable tact of old porcelain, that names have openings and closings the way flowers do, and that the number had been taught to force bloom.

June arrived without knocking because her knocks are songs and the door had learned them and opened early, and she stood just inside the threshold with the dignity of a conductor checking that the brass were not inventing harmonies while she was fetching water, and she listened to the ribbon with that half-turned head teachers keep when they are allowing a child to lie once so the child can hear the sound of it. The ribbon did not speak. It lay there like a belt with a purpose, black and thin and with that sheen that new plastic has before it is touched enough to lose it, and June, whose pupils had taught her everything one can learn about desperation in the breaks between scales, said that if the number will not answer us when we ask nicely, we shall let it find only the wrong mouths when it goes calling. She took from her bag a box of badges that had belonged to a summer two decades ago when you could change your life by wearing a word on your chest and believing it, and she shook the box and the clink sounded like minor money being counted for bus fare, and she said that she had made more since yesterday, that words are quicker than uniforms and less likely to betray you. On the table the badges sat and flashed modestly: Not Yet, Soup, Borrowed, Homeward, Quiet, Again, and the one she kept in her own palm, which said Chorus because it was important someone in the room remembered that people are safest when they are made of more than one.

They used the afternoon as you use the hour before guests arrive, to clear surfaces and assign roles and decide which pieces of honesty could be left in sight without anyone needing to apologise for them, and Lorna ran a towel along the shelf beneath the steel and found that someone, probably herself, had tucked two sachets of sugar and a toothpick there for later and she put them in her pocket with a guilt that had nothing to do with sugar and everything to do with knowing what they were about to do would need sweetening before memory would carry it without injuring the carrier. They called nobody and told nobody who had the power to make it official or to make it stop; they called, instead, those who had been walking around with a sensation that something was happening just beyond the range at which polite people allow themselves to notice, and those who, when asked to hum on a bridge, had hummed because the question had been asked in a voice that did not assume consent but welcomed it. Boys came in ones and twos and in threes that were not always friends but had decided to act like it to feel large, and one or two men who were not boys came with the sort of caution men who have learned to survive learn to wear around younger men so the air remains breathable, and June showed them how to hold a vowel like a lantern in their mouths and how to set it glowing without losing its oxygen.

There was a conversation nobody wanted that had to happen and Mr Cook had it, because if there is a hard talk going, he will fold a napkin exactly and place it in front of it and make it feel attended to, and he told a lad with a mouth like a letter halfway through being inked that the plan was to take his name out of his mouth for an hour and keep it somewhere safe because out there are wrong answers looking for questions, and the boy said which hour and Mr Cook said the one you usually give to luck, and the boy nodded and did not pretend to understand more than the bone of it; that was enough. The bowl waited with its blue patience and took names written on torn paper with the good grace of a plate at a bring-and-share, and when a boy hesitated and looked towards the door as if the door had hands, June stood so that he could see her and said that if it felt like an order he should take his name and go, and he put it down then because she had named his feeling and found a place for it in the room where it would not be stepped on. Lorna used salt as punctuation and drew a ring around the bowl that had the air of a joke that got better with repetition, and Victorine bent her giant carefulness over the table and breathed fog into nothing in particular and the air thickened into something that had the decency not to show off about being protective.

The hour they chose to be cruel to kindness was the hour when fog confuses appetite for destiny, and they spread themselves along three bridges and a path that pretended it wasn’t one because grass had pushed closer, and the hum rose the way soup steam rises when it remembers itself into a kitchen, and Mr Cook removed from his pocket the little folded piece of his first name and tucked it, separately, into the bowl, and the loss of it struck him with an intimacy he had not rehearsed, a thinning at the edge of him that did not make him fragile but made him more honest about where his edges were. He was Mr Cook and Mr Cook was enough to do what needed doing, and the private name that belonged to childhood and to one voice he had never stopped waiting to hear was in a blue room that loved it without asking it to do any work. Victorine hid her own name where it always lives, under the belt of pictures, because she had no new place to put it and because she trusted leather and heat more than any charm, and Lorna, who had never feared her name being used against her except by people she could frighten back with a scarf, wrote it on paper and kissed the corner and put it in the ring because there are times to pretend invulnerability and this was not one.

The Borrower Not Exactly did not come when summoned because this was not a summoning; it was the reverse, a refusal designed with the finesse of a politeness expert, and it tried, instead, the edges where quiet men keep their keys and their apologies. It spoke in the voice of one boy’s father who had never said the boy’s name as if it were nice to taste and the boy flinched and then laughed because the hum held like a tide that had been promised work and delivered, and the call slid off into the river where names go to be smoothed. It called in the voice of someone’s first boyfriend and then in the voice of a woman who had said, slowly and with regret, that she could not teach her son to shave but she could teach him to iron a shirt, and the hum did what June had told it to; it did not argue and it did not win, it merely continued, and in continuing it made the calls bored with themselves. When boredom arrived it came like rain on a bus window when you have forgotten your book; it trickled and it found the oldest route and went down it and became predictable, and then Mr Cook learned the smell of the thing when it is disappointed, a smell like the cardboard of record sleeves after a flood and the skin that forms on hot milk that some people remove and some people fold back under because waste is a sin where they were taught to be hungry.

In the kitchen the bowl’s blue learned a new blue, an undertone as if a sky had remembered a bruise, and the names shivered as paper can shiver, which is to say by waiting, and the ribbon tried tricks that would have rattled eggs if eggs had been in the refrigerator, and the dishwasher watched itself nobly for the chance to be heroic and did not flood because Mr Cook had spoken to it earlier with the small respect he gives machines that can drown him, and the steel held the taste of salt without resenting its ungenerous glamour. The picture of Kellan with the moon scar, which had been erasing itself the way grief removes adjectives first and then nouns, paused at its left edge as if it had encountered a fact it could not argue with, and it held that edge, not receding, not repairing, just holding, which is what victory looks like when you have stopped expecting to win and have not, yet, learned to enjoy it.

When the boys came back for their names the bowl parted with them the way a bowl parts with anything put in it with love: willingly, with precise solemnity, with a faint cling as if ceramics could insist on gratitude and then remember that to insist is unkind, and they unfolded the slips and tasted their names silently to see if any new syllables had been added by fear, and then they tucked them back behind their teeth and went home, slower than usual, because returning from safety requires a new gait. One lad, in the kind of generosity that embarrasses and nourishes in equal measure, asked if there was anything else they could take for a while, and Lorna, who understands transactional ethics because she has worked with people too long not to, told him to take the chairs to the back and stack them neatly and he did and he slept well for the first time in a month because someone had told him what to do with his hands.

They did not get a night off. It never works like that. At three in the morning the blue bowl woke Mr Cook with soundless insistence and he rose and did not groan because the bowl had no time for theatrics and neither, just then, did he, and he found, when he switched on only the small light over the oven because big lights at that hour are a kind of violence, that the ribbon had pushed itself to the lip of the steel and arranged its end as if mimicking a question mark, and in the question mark was the number again, the same rhythm, the same refusal to begin at the beginning, and June’s earlier logic did not fail them: numbers can be taught boredom, too, if you make them do the work of not getting what they expected. He wrote the number on the backsplash in pencil because pencil is a place where information can rest without becoming law, and then he made tea, not because tea fixes anything, but because the kitchen understood tea as a ritual that kept water from becoming cruel.

By dawn they had a new plan, one that could not be made beautiful and would have to be made kind instead, and it involved asking Kellan’s brother for something nobody should have to be asked for and holding that ask carefully enough that the answer could be no without causing harm. They found him not where the paper said he lived but where sorrow takes you when you are too tired to be polite to your own sofa, a bench near a tree that had learned to listen to human names without thinking it was a forest, and Mr Cook explained, slowly, without metaphor and without using any of the words that analogies prefer, that they wanted to take Kellan’s name and put it in a bowl so the thing that answered would have nothing to answer to, and that they would give it back before the city remembered how to be blue in daylight. The brother was the sort of man who has learned to love with an expressionless face because everything else feels like theatre, and he asked if they were making fun of him and they said no the way you say no when your lungs will not forgive you if you lie, and he put his hands together and pulled them apart and looked at what was not there and said all right, but if you break it, you keep the pieces in your mouths and die slow.

He wrote the name on paper with the care of a man signing his name to a mortgage and tore it off with a neatness that suggested he had never torn paper before and wanted to be good at it, and he handed it to Mr Cook who did not take it with two fingers like something he did not want to touch; he cupped it the way you would hold a moth that has come indoors and will die if you insist on keeping it. The bowl took the slip with the same practical holiness it had for all the others and the salt ring said something you could not translate into speech, and for an hour the hum was not a bridge hum but a kitchen hum and the radio, which had rediscovered its purpose and forgiven itself for being co-opted by wrongness, spoke of vessels and fog and gale warnings with the accuracy of a woman who knows what forgetting costs. The Borrower tried the name immediately and it hit the steel the way cutlery hits steel, sharp and without nuance, and the echo was painful and the thing learned a lesson you wish it had never needed to learn, and in that hour the picture of the moon-scar boy gained back the thickness it had been losing and the left edge, which had been slipping like a boundary drawn on bad paper, stopped pretending to be ocean and admitted it was margin.

After, they found their price sitting on the floor like a piece of grit you cannot see but can feel; the bowl had sweated the way cold bowls do when rooms decide to forget themselves warmer, and the blue that loves only its own blue had learned also to hold a streak of grey that was not age but experience, and the ribbon, in a sulk that looked like obedience, lay perfectly straight as if someone had ironed it. Kellan’s brother took the paper back with a politeness that would have been gratitude if he had had the energy for gratitude and he did not say thank you and they did not ask for it, and that was perfect because the room did not have space for thank you, only for fact. He left with the pace of a man carrying a glass and they watched his mouth to see whether the syllables fitted properly and they did, coming and going in the steady way you want breath to come and go, and when he had gone, Lorna declared, with that bravado that is a kindness worn as armour, that the city would soon owe them funding and a plaque, and Mr Cook laughed and felt awesome and ridiculous and alive and heavier.

The day after was ordinary in the way that good weather is ordinary if you grew up near a sea that changes its mind every five minutes, and Victorine took her camera to places where the city wears its age on the outside and asked light to write on her paper in ways that would later tell the truth without humiliating anyone, and the fox ran errands of his own and stole nothing because he had eaten an egg that morning and felt magnanimous, and June sat on her piano stool and taught the metronome a new trick which was to be imprecise on purpose to make the room practice listening. Mr Cook went to the cobbler and asked him, with the air of a man buying a gift of practical undergarments, whether he had any more mispaired shoes in his stories, and the cobbler said he kept a list of men who had asked for left-left pairs and that list was not long but it had a pattern, and he wrote three names on a card with old-fashioned seriousness, all of them the kind of names people choose for themselves when they are trying to begin again. It was not the Borrower’s list. It was a human list, and that was worse, because you can fix a machine with a manual but people bring their own manuals and refuse to admit they did not write them.

They found the promoter again, scarfed and plausible and loud as branding, on a corner that had not asked to be a corner of anything, and Lorna judged him with that flat friendly look that has made generations of liars confess and he confessed—inadvertently, with enthusiasm—to having brought lads to spaces that were not nightclubs but were nights pretending, and to calling them by their names the way one calls dogs in off a road with sincerity and a promise of food and warmth. He had not meant harm. He had meant ease, and ease is a door you can walk through in both directions. Mr Cook took his details the way doctors take details when they have no pills for what is wrong, and he put them on the placemat map in pencil and underlined them with a line that admitted it might not be fair and would be erased if the world agreed. They were not any closer and they were inches closer; this is how you get there, inching in a city that turns its corners into loops when you have not eaten enough.

At night, the radio decided to be generous to those who remembered dates by the weather, and read the Shipping Forecast with a timbre that reminded Mr Cook of his father in the next room working out how to tell him he had not been promoted, and the bowl sat with the weight of all the names it had held and of the ones it would hold, and the ribbon learned to pretend to sleep. Victorine went to the Scott Monument again and felt the wind taste her with a courtesy that comes from long acquaintance, and she was ready this time when it said the Borrower Not Exactly’s true not-name—that impossible letter that looks like a door you can only walk through once—and she pressed it to the inside of her mouth where you keep the things you should not say, and in keeping it she became less lonely for a beat that a drummer would have called needless and which she insisted on counting anyway. Down on the bridge the hum held and a boy stopped himself saying his name twice and then, like all humans, rewarded himself for this good behaviour by breaking another contract with himself, only a little, by texting someone he should not have texted, and nothing bad happened because sometimes nothing bad happens and this should be recorded because hope does not thrive on disasters alone.

They were lucky for three days, which is a length of luck one ought not to explain away with jokes, and on the fourth day the city reminded them that it has multiple departments and none of them coordinate efficiently; a man from the council came to the restaurant with a form about noise complaints and an expectation that he would have to be angry, and Mr Cook gave him coffee and a seat and a slice of something that had begun life as a tart and become, during the shift, a lesson in humility, and the man’s anger went off like a timer in an empty room and he said that he had a son who had stopped answering to his name for fun when he was four and had never started again, and Mr Cook said nothing at all because there are occasions when silence is not passive but an active object you place on the table so that the other person can rest the thing they did not want to show you. The form was not filled. The noise was not counted. The city continued to be itself with and without permission.

What came next was not a plan they would have chosen, but a plan that came and sat in the middle of the kitchen and refused to be ignored, and it arose from the bowl wanting a new thing. Bowls do not want. This one did. It wanted to travel. It wanted to be placed where names entered the city rather than where they were kept safe from it, and this meant the registry office with its kind faceless patience and its pens on strings and its tables that have seen more vows broken and kept than any church, and Lorna said, delighted and appalled, that they were going to go to a government building with a fox and a bowl and a story, and the bowl made its small ceramic noise of assent by existing more blue than it had a right to, and Mr Cook said that if he were going to be arrested for the first time in his life he would prefer it to be on a Wednesday and preferably before lunch, and Victorine decided the ceiling could manage her and the fox shook himself so the hairs lay properly and consented to be carried.

They went at opening time because that is when rooms have not chosen sides yet and you can make your case without being argued with by the ink in the ledgers, and the woman at the desk had hair she had grown to make herself stronger and eyes that had learned discretion as a sacrament, and when they placed the bowl on the counter she looked at it and did not flinch because she had seen birth certificates for names that could cut and for names that would be a cushion and had learned not to show preference. Mr Cook told the story in a way that did not make it into a story, which is to say he walked the woman through a set of decisions none of which were posed as choices, and he said that there was a thing in the city that did not understand questions and was dangerous because of that, and they had taught it boredom and harm reduction and wanted now to set a basin at a spring so that what ran into it would not be wasted. She listened and pressed her lips together the way a person presses seams so they will lie flat, and then she rose and went into a back room and the room behind the back room, and when she returned she brought with her a stamp that had seen more of love than most people and a little sachet of rice, and she poured the rice into the bowl and said that in her house they always put rice in bowls and said the names they needed kept safe over it and that she would be in trouble for this and she did not care.

They put no names into it there; they only let it learn the feel of the place where names are made into letters and into entries and into legal bits of paper, and the bowl learned; you could see it, which is ridiculous and true, and when someone came to register a child and said the name in the voice of someone who had practised in a kitchen for a week and did not believe they would be allowed to say it outside, the bowl heard and did nothing, which was the point, and then it was over and they took their ridiculous, holy object back into the street and no one stopped them because the street was on their side that morning and doors had chosen not to argue. Later, when the Borrower tried again to find a road into a mouth by saying a new name in a perfect voice, it discovered that perfection is unpersuasive when you have made acquaintance with a counter where a woman who knows rice did not laugh at a blue bowl.

That night, at last, the city asked for its due in effort, not in blood, and they were up and down the closes until their calves wrote strongly worded letters to their spines, and the hum broke and was mended and broke again because bodies are instruments and instruments go out of tune at the edge of fear, and the ribbon tried to take a door it was not allowed, and Victorine pressed her thumb and said no and no and no until the word lost the taste of refusal and became simply a shape air can choose, and Mr Cook, tired enough to be honest without fearing the consequences, told a boy with a mouth like a hinge that the way he kissed would not save him but might teach him something about listening if he let it, and the boy laughed and did not call his friends to laugh with him and that was, in itself, a win. They ended at June’s because June’s was where things ended now when they had not ended badly and had not ended completely, and she made them sit and fed them something with butter and sugar and salt that was not fancy and could not be improved upon, and when Mr Cook put his head down on the table not because he was sad but because his muscles had misfiled themselves and could not, just then, be found, June put her hand on the back of his neck with the expertise of a woman who has adjusted a thousand heads to meet their own breath without argument and he breathed and his name, still in the bowl, slept.

It will not hold, Victorine thought, because nothing does and because the world will not allow a woman to get away with loving this loudly without adding a bill, and she was right and also not right, because holding is not the same as winning and you can hold a thing long enough for something else to arrive, a bus or a boy or a new agreement with gravity, and she looked out of June’s window at a street that was temporarily uninterested in stealing, and she allowed herself to imagine a time when her belt would be light and the photographs would live on walls without pinholes and when mouths would be left to be mouths and not maps, and she took the ribbon from the steel and laid it on the piano because pianos forgive and the ribbon, absurdly, visibly, behaved. The fox dreamed with his feet jerking, as if running through the grasses of a countryside he had never been to, and Lorna dreamed with her mouth open because propriety is a game and she had won enough rounds this week and could put it down, and Mr Cook dreamed with his name in a bowl and did not wake when the bowl hummed once, quietly, a note of recognition for the registry counter where names had become themselves and had not been borrowed for bad magic; he slept because sometimes the city will allow it, and because sleep is an agreement with the morning that you will try again when you can carry your own plate to the sink without dropping it.

Morning leaned on the city as if it had been invited to sit and could not decide whether to take the armchair or the floor, and Mr Cook, who wakes now as if light were a polite knock, counted the new noises as if they were receipts: the timid clang of bottles in the lane, the radio doing its vowels with a mouth that refused to show off, the fox dislodging something beneath the hedge and withholding the information because it enjoys secrets. The blue bowl was where he had left it, which is to say in the place the kitchen had made for it by moving itself half an inch to one side, and the paper slips inside had settled like birds on a branch when wind has been. He touched the rim and felt that kindness again, the hospitality of a house that does not insist on its rules if you arrive with your hands out and your breath honest, and for a moment he permitted himself contentment the way you permit a child to run along a wall as long as the wall is low; then he saw the sheen along the inner curve that had not been there yesterday, not a crack, no, a very old word the bowl had found and liked—crazing, the fine map lines a life leaves when it is asked to carry more patience than was printed on the box. He did not panic. He did what you do when you live with vulnerable objects; he adjusted the room so that it would not ask for any new tricks and he told the bowl out loud that they would not be careless with it and in saying it he meant everything else that could break.

Victorine arrived with her coat fog-damp to the elbow and her hair smelling of the Forth and the toothpaste of a stranger she had walked past in a close and loved briefly for the way he had believed in mint, and she set her camera down in the manner of someone who has decided to be forgiving in advance. The ribbon lay with the indolence of a cat that has found the patch of sun; Victorine did not trust it, as one does not trust the sun in Glasgow in March, which is a separate religion altogether, but she acknowledged the courtesy of its stillness. Lorna came in arguing with her scarf about subclauses and kugels and whether colour can be used diagnostically, and she stopped when she saw the bowl’s new fine lines and made a face that had been perfected at nine when someone had dropped a church plate and the adults had decided to rename the noise accident. She did not say the thing itched behind her teeth about glue and gold because not all metaphors need to be invited to the party; she touched the bowl in the place the lines had not reached, as if implying a direction for future imperfection, and the bowl accepted this supervisory affection with the dignity of ceramic that has hosted rice.

He came as if a door in him had been wedged with a spoon and then withdrawn and he had stepped forward because forward was what the room expected. A boy, no older than twenty, with a mouth that was a little too practical for his eyes and a coat that had learned to keep his weather to itself, standing in the doorway of the restaurant during the hour when the room rehearses being a room and has not yet invited people to be their better selves at its tables. He hesitated as one does on company thresholds when one is holding nothing you can pretend is a present, and then he said nothing, and then he said more nothing, and Lorna, who is a librarian of silences in addition to everything else her job is not paying for, moved towards him with hands that did not reach for his, and asked, gently as if carrying china, what name he would like her to use. It would have been comic if it were not the exact right question. The boy opened his mouth and no name arrived. Sound did, and the sound brought with it air and the air got him as far as a syllable that could have been the start of seventeen different lives and then he shook his head and pressed his lips together and frowned, and Mr Cook, who has a doctorate in frowns and their implications, recognised the particular anguish of a man who had been asked to perform his name and discovered that the instrument had been borrowed without permission.

They did not make a festival of it. They did not cry out that their theory had been proven, that the Borrower Not Exactly had returned something not in pieces but inside out. They made tea and sat him at the corner table under the radio and laid down paper and offered pens as if he were a man about to write the first letter of his first language and the room would wait as long as it took. He did not write. He held the pen as if he were checking whether it was sharp enough to defend him and then as if he had missed a step and found himself, luckily, still upright. Victorine stood far enough back that the air would not have to choose between the boy and the fact of her, and she had to put her hand to her belt because an old habit twitched—she almost reached for him with paper. She almost took the soft boundary that had been made vulnerable so she could keep it safe, which is love and theft at once. She did not. The boy’s mouth was not hers to keep. She watched instead the way his lower lip tried to remember a vowel and did not find it, and she hummed very quietly, a hum that did not try to persuade, only to console, and the radio, because radios are mimics when they're good, lowered itself into a Shipping Forecast like a warm bath.

June arrived because some rooms summon her by habit now without anyone calling and because she needed somewhere to wait with her hands not being used to cradle a student’s fear while the student pretended not to tremble. She looked at the boy and saw at once that there was no wound to bind, there was an absence to guard, and she said, not to him, not to anyone, Try “I”. He tried. It came out like a door edge catching. She stepped closer, made a shape with her lips that he could mirror without feeling mocked, and said “I” in a way that put the vowel on the table in front of him as a sweet, a manageable, safe thing, and he did it, and Mr Cook watched the boy’s throat move and saw the little gratitude that always arrives when someone grants you the first person, and he nearly wept because he is not unaccustomed to being the person people say I to for the first time in a night. They gave him a badge from June’s box—Borrowed, because it is possible to be merciless and merciful at once if the word is precisely chosen—and he pinned it with the ceremony of a liability becoming an asset.

He could not give a name, but he could give other truths, which is how you recognise a person and not a system. He told them, after he learned “I” and “here” and “hungry,” that he had a left foot that was two millimetres smaller than his right, that he carried his keys on a lanyard because he liked to be punished with noise for forgetfulness, that his grandmother had died in the spring and he had learned that grief has pollen, that he could make a Yorkshire pudding rise with a frown if forced, that he had kissed a boy under a tree whose name he could not say now not because it was gone but because saying it would break the boy, and that he had come because the radio in the restaurant hummed a note he had known before he knew language and he had followed it as you follow an old smell up stairs that have not learned your steps. He could not say who he was. It did not make him less. It made him more to them, actually, because love will always prefer the particular to the legal. Lorna gave him soup and told him she loved a man once who needed three spoons for breakfast and left two at home out of spite and he laughed, a real laugh, which is a document more binding than anything at a registry.

Outside, the city was shedding its labels the way a tired person rubs off the dampness behind their knees and tells nobody. They noticed first on the way to the shop for milk when Mr Cook lifted his eyes to the corner and saw the street name misbehaving. Not missing—worse. Slid. The metal screws still bit the stone. The enamel rectangle bearing the word had surrendered and been walked with two inches to the left so that the word did not point where the street actually went. A kindness if you liked to be lost; a cruelty if you had an appointment with dignity. They walked, separately and then together, and saw more: a plaque that had been politely rotated so that the man in bronze died by a different river; an alley that could no longer remember whether it was a Close or a Wynd and had started answering to Lane; a brass letter gone missing so that Bread became Read and the baker grinned once and then did not. Names matter to cities because they are shortcuts for breath. Somebody was changing shortcuts and asking lungs to improvise.

The promoter had been leaning on their map for weeks like a child at the counter of the sweet shop he can just reach and pretending that he worked here so that if trouble came it would not ask him for the bill. They went to him because he had a power they could harness that would not bring uniforms and checklists into rooms that could not bear them; he could put a message into a night and make it viral not by algorithm but by personality. Lorna was sent because he liked her and wanted to be liked by her and it would make the conversation faster. She put a scarf around her mouth because she knows the trick in theatres where you cannot move the spotlight but you can make its job easy, and she asked him to do nothing, to restrain himself from what he thinks he does well, and he nearly said yes immediately because he would have done anything exactly opposite of flattery for her. She told him not to call names at doors. She told him to call not-names instead, the words from June’s box, Loud, Homeward, Soup, Borrowed, Always, Quiet, Again, and he did not laugh because he is smarter than that, he is a man who has looked at his habits and found his mother in them and learned to ask for fussing in other ways. He made a post, then three, that said Tonight we’re not doing names, we’re doing roles, we’re doing conditions, we’re doing we. He did it with a wit that made the belligerent soften because being funny is sometimes less manipulative than being sincere. Boys turned up at doors and said their badge words and were admitted and the Borrower, which learns instruction sets faster than it learns songs, made a noise somewhere between fur and paper and was denied a few easy meals.

The bowl complained in a new language that afternoon, not with sound, with temperature: it cooled in the middle as if a coin had been pressed to it and removed and inside the cool was a shape like a mouth left open under water. Mr Cook rested his fingers on it and felt, with that new, intolerable sensitivity his life had grown, that somewhere someone was practicing an ask. He told the bowl, which may have been for himself, to keep his name asleep very deep and not to answer even if it is asked in the voice of someone who knows where he keeps his receipts. He did not say out loud that what he feared now was not the Borrower learning how to ask; it was the Borrower learning how to listen. He wrote on the placemat map another line, a shallow snake where the street names had been shifted, and the biro obeyed him even though it was tired and could have been forgiven for giving up.

They took the bowl to a potter in Abbeyhill who has the hands of a person who has taught earth to wait and has forgiven the earth for its impatience. The potter looked at the fine map of lines and nodded in the manner of women in white aprons in rooms where theatre is not welcome. She said there is a crack that can be sung closed and there is a crack that, if you sing at it, will sing back and split you for your trouble. She ran her fingertip along the inside of the crazing as if reading the minute gossip of the glaze, pressed her ear to the lip as if a seashell lived here, and said that this bowl wants ink in its wounds, not gold. Kintsugi is a romance for bowls that want to show off their damage and call it style. Your bowl prefers secrets. She made them a thin solution of soot and starch and vinegar and told them to paint the very finest lines with the very finest brush and then to put the bowl in a warm place and tell it three stories about patience. Lorna took the brush because her hands are small and obey her and Victorine told the first story and June the second and Mr Cook the third, which was about the night he stayed at work an hour after close because the dishwasher spoke anxiously, and it worked the way love often does: not on the surface at once, but underneath, in the bit that will hold next time.

Victorine’s belt was heavier every day with proofs she needed and proofs she had been made to keep by the logic of her own vow, and that afternoon she admitted to an idea that had been tapping politely on her shoulder for two days: to spend photographs like coin. It broke one of her rules but rules are cheap when boys are disappearing and the city is tired of being misnamed. She took five of the squares she had sworn to hoard and she climbed to a roof because roofs are chapter headings whether you like it or not, and she made, with her huge careful hands, little birds out of them. They were not perfect birds, but they were undeniably creaturely, and she set them on the parapet and breathed on them and said, Go where someone needs to remember their mouth is theirs, and she did not know whether she meant the boys or the Borrower or the city. They did what paper does in Edinburgh when asked for flight; they remembered all the wind that had come before and they behaved like writing. You could have seen them anywhere that day: caught on a pinboard outside a bar with the oily thumbprint of an owner who had been moved against his traditions, in the slot of a letterbox where an old woman reached and thought for a second she was being returned something she had not asked back for, on the lap of a statue that had finally been kissed. It cost her, the way giving away proof costs; it made the book in her head less certain, it hastened the day when her belt would be light and her grief would not know what to eat. She did it anyway, because men were not being kept safe by rhetoric.

Stability held as long as it could under the new rules, which is to say half a day. The Borrower Not Exactly arrived in a different coat—the shoulders were almost perfect now, which is sinister, and the shoes were worn in the correct place by being deliberately scuffed with a rock by someone who had been told where to aim—and it tried its new trick on the person least inclined to treat tricks like entertainment. It waited until Lorna was hauling a bag of lemons out of a taxi and said, in a voice she had not known she had teaching rights over, What do you want. It was not the man with the scarf or the boy with the letter mouth or any of the city’s decent rough men. It was her father, but not; it was the voice he would have used if he had loved her enough to make choice sound like a promise and not a threat. She did not drop the lemons because the muscles that lift sacks are not the ones questions break. She put the bag down. She did not turn. She said, clear as a closing statement in a room with no judge, We are closed. The sentence behaved like holy water on nonsense. The man making himself a coat flickered, a haddock under the surface, and was bored. Boredom is the instrument their choir has learned. It left because it preferred being feared and could not find fear in people carrying citrus.

The signs kept changing and they kept changing them back with chalk because chalk has no time to be precious and because returning a name to a wall is the same work as returning a name to a mouth; you find the place where gravity has been misapplied and you lean. Mr Cook became an expert at the way municipal screws lie to you and at how much pressure enamel can take before it says mind yourself, and he made friends with a man with a van who is gentle with awkwardness and will come when rung because he has been rung in worse circumstances, and the man brought a screwdriver set that has learned compromise. They began to get good at it. A street noticed. It is not nonsense; the city notices when its handles are held properly. Bruntsfield Links held its own letters still for a night, as if in gratitude, and the Meadows, which has always been a place that forgives lying down, forgave two boys for lying down in a part where grass is not a good idea, and the fox watched and did not roll his eyes.

It felt for a minute like they had tricked disaster into being a job and then disaster remembers itself by getting personal. The boy with the moon of a scar came through the door of the restaurant carrying a smile like a tea tray, and if you had written the moment down simply—Boy returns, scar intact, says hello—you would have abased yourself before the miracle and gone home to sleep. But the boy did not say hello. He opened his mouth and the first thing that came out was the number Mr Cook had not called, and the number trembled a little as if not convinced of its own place here, and then the boy spoke with absolutely ordinary ease about tea and sauce and whether this napkin liked him and what time it was in Paris, and Mr Cook was happy and angry and ecstatically relieved and then he hit the wall of shame that is meeting a return not with gratitude but with an audit. He looked at the mouth and listened for the inside voice and could not hear it, and it was terrible, because how do you tell someone who has been delivered to you not exactly wrong that they may have been brought back right in a way that does not include themselves. He did not tell. He did his job, which is not to take from people what they bring. He fed him. He watched his hands. He watched the way he checked his pockets, and saw nothing that looked like a coding error. It would take days. They had given the Borrower boredom. It had returned the favour by giving them doubt so slender you could sharpen a thought on it.

They had a plan and hated it, which is a sign of good planning. They would take Mr Cook’s hidden name, the one the blue bowl warmed and the kitchen took care of as if it housed a bird that would sing if allowed but would catch cold if asked, and they would set it in the path of the thing that had learned to ask questions and see whether it could be trained to enjoy being wrong. June spoke against it in the way generous women speak against harm they will do anyway if it is the only not-harm left; she said that teaching the Borrower the shape of a good question would, necessarily, involve admitting that good questions often get answers and that the person asked risks having to travel. Victorine said she would go in his place inside the word if she could, and there was a moment when the air in the room was a decision, and then the fox sneezed because the pepper had been left open and the spell was broken and they hung their coats of resolution back on the pegs where promises live.

The city, which has seen worse, yawned around sunset and sat down to wait for whatever it had been promised by this new crop of amateurs with their bowls and their choir and their dignified insolence. Men on ladders put lights up across streets to pretend it was always festival and not survival, and girls in jackets put glitter on their cheeks because not all magic is municipal and sometimes the glamour you need is the kind you make and wipe away, and the promoter stood on a chair outside a venue and shouted Not your name, your word, and boys held up their badges and said Soup like a prayer, and no one was embarrassed because they had been given a format that kept humiliation at bay. The Borrower tried to learn glitter and failed because glitter is loyal to trouble but not to boredom. It pivoted and went to the docks and walked along looking for old names in rust. It found plenty and found them poor substitutes for the fresh flowers it had acquired the taste for. It called them anyway as a child will call the names of ships when no one is watching, and the emptiness answered like a gull.

Victorine went to sea to ask permission because she refuses to be the sort of mythical creature that helps itself to powers invented by people who have not walked in rain. She stood on the pier in Leith and bent and put her ear to the rail like a woman trying to hear whether the train inside the metal has chosen sides yet, and she asked the Forth if it would allow her to take a picture of a reflection and not the face, and the Forth, which knows about duplicity and does not get excited about it, said with a slap against a tire that it did not mind as long as she looked at the water when she pressed the shutter. She did. A mouth looked back up at her from below that was not a face attached to a boy and not a face attached to a man but something else, and its lips moved around a name that even she would not grant her camera. She took the picture anyway because permission had been granted by the only authority she would not argue with and because the act felt exactly like penance and throughout the city there was, for an hour, a dryness that did not belong to the air and did not last.

They carried the blue bowl to the bridge and set it in the light that is not light, the one June knows how to coax from breath, and Mr Cook took the little piece of paper with the first name he had not used and placed it inside on a bed that was not rice and not salt but napkins folded so precisely you would think someone polite was coming and he climbed back into his own body as if he had been standing outside it for the duration of a small errand. The Borrower came just as badly as a late guest who believes themselves irresistible. It wore no coat at all now, which is a threat or an apology depending on the angle, and it asked, with the new trick of hesitation that it had always lacked, What do you want, Mr— and then it opened its mouth for the name it had not been given and the hum was a hand set flat against it. Mr Cook heard his own name as he had never heard it, between other people’s breath, and he did not answer because he is capable of not being polite when the situation requires it. He did what Lorna had done. He used the phrase that makes a boundary out of air. He said, We are closed. He said it as if closing were not a refusal but an act of caretaking, as if you shut doors so you can open them later, and the thing that borrows paused, not in boredom, this time in a new experience altogether. It had been refused as one refuses, and it looked at him with a curiosity that felt like being slowly read by someone who will not skip any words.

It left him there with his name in the bowl and walked around and tried the trick on the blue. The blue did not answer and later when he held the bowl in his hands he could feel where the question had fallen on the glaze like rain. He dried it with a towel the way a man dries a child out of the bath and the towel remembered him for it. Victorine took the square from her camera, the one that had been developed in the salt of the Forth, and laid it beside the ribbon with mutual suspicion arranged like a centrepiece, and the ribbon did not leap and the square did not burn and the radio read the capes of the British Isles like a rosary and the fox climbed onto a chair and sat as if a meeting had been convened for his benefit and everyone had forgotten why.

News spread as it does, along wires that are not wires and through the medium of the out-breath. A boy who had learned the hum taught it to his mother without explanation and she found herself at the sink later whispering vowels into the water and refusing to be embarrassed by the sensation of being old and new at once. The council man came back with a badge June had given him tucked under his lapel where only rituals could see it, and he did not talk about forms. He talked about a sign on a building that held a name for people who want to become families that had been turned to face the wall, and he turned it back, and for the first time in days he felt his job had done good that did not hurt anyone. A pile of left shoes appeared on the steps of a church because guilt is practical, and the vicar, who has seen almost everything and has the posture of a man who has been allowed to be tired, looked at them and knew that it is not his job to ask how. He arranged them as if someone might come for them later when the story permitted mercy.

There was a failure because it would be indecent to forget to record one. A boy stood on a bridge at two and forgot his badge and forgot his hum and answered to a name in a voice that tasted like Irish stout and parental permission and he went with the man with the exact shoulders and they disappeared into a warehouse that Mr Cook had not yet drawn on his placemat because he believes in the decency of paper and had wanted to spare it a grievance it could not address. They did not save him. They were not there. The next day the plate of his mouth was returned to a photograph in Victorine’s belt in the careless way a child returns a borrowed book to the nearest flat surface and she cried, silently and messily, because consent had been vandalised, and it cost her nothing but the proof that a god would have taken and she does not know how to make gods and refuses to. They did what they do when they cannot undo: they told the city his name without using it, by carrying his bag for a week in their hands and by asking a waitress in a cafe to sit down and by picking up a dropped phone and leaving it on a bench where the original owner could imagine finding it.

At the end of a long day of this kind of measuring success in edible spoons, June said that they should put the bowl on the piano because a bowl that wants to travel and learn places needs to learn patience sitting with instruments that were designed for it. They did. The bowl agreed with the wood. It learned to resonate in a register that was not domestic. It learned to accept applause without cultivating a taste for it. It sat while June played the accompaniment to a song that children learn when a teacher who remembers how to teach has time, and it had to bear Lorna’s scarf again because the room was not warm enough and she had decided that the scarf was now a garment for objects that might catch a cold. Mr Cook put his forehead to the lid for a minute and let it carry him and then he took a breath and stood up and went back to the restaurant because service does not forgive itself if you excuse it twice.

There is a way of living in which every ordinary gesture becomes a ritual because the things that used to be solid—the names of streets, the invitations to speak, the usefulness of uniforms—have become polite suggestions and you need somewhere to put your certainty. Mr Cook learned to wipe a counter as if he were writing to the Borrower a sentence that begins, Not today, and to lift a glass as if he were about to bless it with the safety of anonymity, and to answer the phone with the briskness of a doctor whose waiting room has the right number of chairs. Victorine learned to stand smaller without shrinking and to talk less even to herself because words learn secrets whether you intend them to or not, and to sleep in pieces and to accept that her belt will one day be light and this will be called an ending by people who were not there for the middle. Lorna learned to teach the hum to girls who sell shots with names that make men brag their false tolerance and to Patrol the boards where boys still insisted on photographs and to remove the ones that had been tampered with without making a fuss that would taste like fame later.

The city settled into the new arrangement the way a person settles into a new pair of shoes that are exactly right and still raise a blister on the third day. It did not complain loudly. It put its head down on the table when nobody was looking and cried twice and washed its face and got back on with it. The Borrower Not Exactly did not go away because things that are made of our habits rarely do. It altered its timetable and it began to ask questions that were easier to turn away because they reminded you of being a child who had just learned please and did not yet understand that please is not a master key. It lost interest for an afternoon and took three street signs instead in a walk along the curve of a road that thinks it is a river, and the signs were found later at the bottom of a stairwell where two boys kissed because they were late for an argument and had decided to reschedule the argument for a time when arguments were more likely to make things better. The signs were returned and someone wrote with a marker on the pole, WE KNOW YOU LOVE NAMES. COME INSIDE, and the fact that they had written COME INSIDE on a pole made Lorna choke and laugh until she had to sit.

When the council brought railings to the bridges, because the story about bicycles and danger had been escalated in the appropriate manner and the city enjoys its theatre, Mr Cook wrote a letter as he had promised saying thank you, and he meant it, and he wore a tie he had not worn since he had told a landlord that he would not be cowed and the landlord had believed him because the tie had been expensive enough to imply a measure of safety. They stood with mugs of tea at midnight and watched as men with the right tools made edges that would not permit boys to misjudge the choice between leaning and falling, and the Borrower stood a little to the left and pretended it was a lamppost and learned nothing useful because railings belong to the part of the city that enjoys prevention, and it is a vintage it does not drink.

At last, when it had been almost quiet for two days and silence had become a sound you could rest your spine against, the bowl asked to be placed by the window with human words, and Mr Cook looked at June and June looked at Lorna and Lorna looked at Victorine and they decided to behave as if asking had been enough and not demand an essay. They placed it on the sill where steam looks for glass to bless. Outside, the name of the street had been restored precisely and the fox was carrying a slice of pizza with the solemnity of a person delivering organ donations. The bowl looked out at the reflection of its own blue in the pane and made the softest noise a bowl can make without being touched, and Victorine said she thought perhaps it wanted to see whether it could keep something safe through glass, and Mr Cook laughed a small laugh because that is the vocabulary of his whole life. He laid his name in it again because the dish has become a house and the house does not object to children making dens in the same corner every time, and then he went to the door because someone had knocked in the pattern people who come only when something matters use without knowing they do it, and when he opened it the boy with no name and the boy with the moon scar were there, not touching, not brothers, but arranged by need the way tables arrange themselves in a restaurant when you miscount and it still works.

They came in and sat and the hum rose without being asked and the radio smelled of rain and the ribbon lay exactly as long as it had to and the picture from the Forth admitted that whatever she had asked the sea for, she had received a call and had declined it, and in that refusal there was a new step to walk. The Borrower Not Exactly stood in the lane and learned the new ritual of civilians: to walk away because the room is filled with people who have agreed to mean what they say for the next hour, and it stood there a second longer than it needed to and made a little sound that could have been admiration and could have been the elastic snapping in a cheap shoe. The city exhaled. Mr Cook fetched bowls. Lorna told the boys the story about the lemons without embellishment. June tuned the air with the pinch of her fingers as if it were dough and the fox, who is pious in his own way, sat by the door and watched the weather to make sure it did not change without telling them.
